The Electric Reliability Council of Texas, or ERCOT, in its seasonal reliability report, said the state‚Äôs power grid is prepared for the summer and has ‚Äúsufficient‚Äù power for ‚Äúnormal‚Äù summer conditions, based on average weather from 2006 to 2020.

But NOAA‚Äôs recently released summer outlook forecasts above average temperatures for every county in the nation.

‚ÄúWe are continuing to design and site facilities based on historical weather patterns that we know in the age of climate change are not a good proxy for future conditions,‚Äù Webb told CNN.

When asked if the agency is creating a blind spot for itself by not accounting for extreme weather predictions, an ERCOT spokesperson told CNN the report ‚Äúuses a scenario approach to illustrate a range of resource adequacy outcomes based on extreme system conditions, including some extreme weather scenarios.‚Äù

The North American Electric Reliability Corporation, or NERC ‚Äî a regulating authority that oversees the health of the nation‚Äôs electrical infrastructure ‚Äî has a less optimistic projection.

In a recent seasonal reliability report, NERC placed Texas at ‚Äúelevated risk‚Äù for blackouts this summer. It also reported that while much of the nation will have adequate electricity this summer, several markets are at risk of energy emergencies.

California grid operators in its summer reliability report also based its readiness analysis on ‚Äúthe most recent 20 years of historical weather data.‚Äù The report also notes the assessment ‚Äúdoes not fully reflect more extreme climate induced load and supply uncertainties.‚Äù

Compounding the US power grid‚Äôs supply and demand problem is drought: NERC tells CNN there‚Äôs been a 2% loss of reliable hydropower from the nation‚Äôs power-producing dams. Add to that the rapid retirement of many coal power plants ‚Äî all while nearly everything from toothbrushes to cars are now electrified. Energy experts say adding more renewables into the mix will have the dual impact of cutting climate change inducing greenhouse gas emissions but also increasing the nation‚Äôs power supply.

Plan B

One Chicago neighborhood is already making plans for how to keep the lights, air conditioning and heat on when the larger grid fails.

In the Bronzeville neighborhood on Chicago‚Äôs South Side, solar panels dot the rooftop of a public housing complex. A short drive away, a a giant battery stores energy from the solar panels as well as natural gas generators, creating a micro grid. Ilinois-based energy company, Commonwealth Edison, is working with community members to make the neighborhood energy independent.

‚ÄúWithout power we are talking about potential life-threatening situations, so this micro grid provides that backup to be able to deliver power even when the [main] grid isn‚Äôt there,‚Äù said Paul Pabst, an engineer for Commonwealth Edison.

The project is pending approval but once it‚Äôs operating, the micro grid can connect and share power with the main grid. In the event of a blackout, it can disconnect and operate independently, tapping its stored battery energy to power the homes, police station and hospital in the area for four hours.

Yami Newell is a Bronzeville resident and energy advocate. She has seen the cascading effects of an unreliable power grid in Chicago, a place that‚Äôs no stranger to weather-related outages from both extreme cold and extreme heat. Losing power in a heatwave can create a dangerous health situation, and for families on a fixed income, losing all of the food in their refrigerator can be financially devastating.

‚ÄúAn energy crisis can become a public health crisis,‚Äù Newell told CNN. ‚ÄúIt can become a food crisis.‚Äù

As communities look for innovative ways to build a more resilient grid, Bronzeville is one possible blueprint. Until states build a more resilient power grid, climate change will force energy companies to continue to take emergency actions, like asking people to limit electricity use or forced rolling blackouts to manage the grid when supply can‚Äôt meet demand.

search_result.title: Tropical Storm Lee forms in Atlantic: Is Lee going to hit Florida?
search_result.text:
Latest updates Wednesday: Hurricane forecasters say Lee is strengthening

Tropical Storm Lee formed in the Atlantic Ocean far east of the United States on Tuesday afternoon and is expected to become a major hurricane, with winds approaching 150 mph by the weekend.

The question is where is it going? And could it impact the U.S.?

"Interests across the Caribbean and along the East Coast from Florida to Maine will need to pay close attention to this feature," AccuWeather meteorologist Brandon Buckingham said. "Depending on the path this system takes, the expected time frame for potential impacts to the United States and Atlantic Canada may be Sept. 13-16."

Lee, with 65 mph winds, is more than 1,200 miles east of the Caribbean islands, the National Hurricane Center said. The hurricane could bring impacts to the Leeward islands by the weekend, but it's too early to determine how close the storm could approach the islands, hurricane specialist Eric Blake, wrote in the center's 5 pm. Tuesday update.

Rapid intensification likely

"It is becoming a question of when and not if rapid intensification occurs with Lee," Blake said. The forecast now predicts Lee will become a Category 4, 140-mph hurricane by Saturday morning east of Puerto Rico and continue strengthening into a 145-mph storm by Sunday.

A reduction in wind shear in its path along with warm ocean water of near 86 degrees will create favorable conditions for Lee to strengthen, Blake wrote, and several models call for higher winds than those in the center's new forecast. Wind shear tears apart developing storms, while warm water acts as fuel to power up storms.

Prediction and timing of winds, as of 5 a.m. Wednesday:

12 hours: 80 mph (Category 1)

24 hours: 90 mph

48 hours: 120 mph (Category 3)

60 hours: 140 mph (Category 4)

72 hours: 150 mph (Category 4)

96 hours: 150 mph

120 hours: 150 mph

Track forecast uncertain

Latest indications suggest the storm track could vary across a wide swath spanning from the coast northward to eastern Canada, or even skirt away from the coast entirely, AccuWeather said.

Many of the models forecasters use indicate the hurricane is likely to head northward in the Atlantic, but not all. Any bump westward in the track could be disastrous for the Atlantic Coast anywhere from Florida to Nova Scotia.

While that thought is alarming, weather models show a deep trough of low pressure over the eastern U.S. next week, and that dip in the jet stream "should turn Lee more to the north around this time next week," said Ryan Truchelut, chief meteorologist at Florida-based Weather Tiger.

"Unless something very weird happens, that northward movement should occur well east of Florida, and Lee does not look like a threat to the state," Truchelut said.

According to Weather.com meteorologist Jonathan Erdman, "a combination of factors will determine where the hurricane eventually goes" as it makes its way across the Atlantic.

T‚Äãhis includes how strong and expansive the Bermuda-Azores high-pressure area is at the time. "This acts as a steering wheel for tropical waves, storms and hurricanes in the tropics," Erdman said. If the high is weaker, Lee may just recurve out to sea. If it's stronger, then the storm could impact the East Coast of the U.S., he said.

The most likely outcome is that Lee remains offshore, Truchelut said. "But with Lee 10 or more days out, there is sufficient uncertainty in the forecast such that the Eastern Seaboard should keep close tabs on Lee, especially as it will be a strong hurricane."

What is the Saffir-Simpson scale?Breaking down the hurricane category scale

Hurricane center's forecast track:

The forecast track shows the most likely path of the center of the storm. It does not illustrate the full width of the storm or its impacts, and the center of the storm is likely to travel outside the cone up to 33% of the time.

Take a look at the spaghetti models

Special note about spaghetti models: Illustrations include an array of forecast tools and models, and not all are created equal. The hurricane center uses only the top four or five highest-performing models to help make its forecasts.

Most spaghetti models keep the storm north of the Caribbean. However, Bermuda could face a major hurricane next week.

More storms for US?Climate change could push more hurricanes toward US coasts, new study suggests

Dangerous impacts possible even if it stays offshore

A National Weather Service forecast office in eastern North Carolina reminded residents Tuesday that "even when tropical systems stay out to sea, there are still distant impacts locally (dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves, etc.)."

In addition, the weather service said that "every system that develops always serves as a reminder to finish general hurricane season preparations if you haven't already."

How is the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season stacking up?

Lee is the 12th named storm to form this season. If it does become a hurricane, it would be the season's fourth hurricane and third major hurricane.

An average hurricane season produces 14 named storms and seven hurricanes. Even before the season started, forecasters said 2023 was likely to be a busier-than-normal season, but in August they bumped up their predictions, calling for 14-21 named storms.

Contributing: Cheryl McCloud, USA TODAY Network

CNN ‚Äî

Nearly 177 million Americans ‚Äì or more than half the US population ‚Äì will await Christmas weekend under wind chill alerts as a major arctic blast plunges temperatures to dangerous levels in much of the country, according to the National Weather Service.

And the snowiest part is yet to come as the perilous winter storm barrels east across the nation.

A developing ‚Äúbomb cyclone‚Äù is set to unload heavy snow and blizzard conditions especially in the Midwest on Thursday and Friday.

The cold air and storm are affecting nearly every state in some way: More than 200 million people coast-to-coast were under winter-weather alerts for snow or icy conditions Thursday evening, the weather service said.

Wind chill alerts are impacting people from the Canadian border to the Mexican border and from Washington state to Florida, with below-zero wind chills recorded as far south as Texas on Thursday morning and expected in the Southeast by Friday.

‚ÄúLife-threatening wind chills over the Great Plains (will) overspread the eastern half of the nation by Friday,‚Äù the Weather Prediction Center said ‚Äì and wind chills below minus 50 degrees already have been reported in the past two days in parts of Montana, South Dakota and Wyoming.

FOLLOW LIVE UPDATES

Some low temperature records were set Thursday morning in the West and South, and in some cases they dropped this week with record-breaking speed: Denver International Airport saw a 37-degree plunge over one hour Wednesday, preliminarily the biggest one-hour drop recorded there, according to the National Weather Service.

Snow, meanwhile, has been hitting parts of the West and is expected in the next two days across much of the country‚Äôs eastern half.

A major snowstorm is shaping up for the Midwest and Great Lakes especially ‚Äì with widespread light to moderate snowfall ‚Äì but with powerful winds that may make for impossible travel conditions.

‚ÄúHeavy snowfall rates‚Äù of 1 to 2 inches per hour, ‚Äúalong with wind gusts of over 50 mph will result in near-zero visibility and considerable blowing and drifting of snow,‚Äù the prediction center said.

The storm is expected to become a ‚Äúbomb cyclone‚Äù ‚Äì a rapidly strengthening storm that drops a certain amount of pressure within 24 hours ‚Äì Thursday evening into Friday, reaching the pressure equivalent of a Category 2 hurricane as it moves into the Great Lakes. This could be ‚Äúa once in a generation type of event,‚Äù a forecaster in the weather service‚Äôs Buffalo office wrote Tuesday, after noting that kind of strengthening doesn‚Äôt often happen in the lower Great Lakes.

A blizzard warning will be in place at 7 a.m. Friday in Buffalo and surrounding communities, where one to three feet of snow and 70 mph wind gusts are likely, according to the National Weather Service.

‚ÄúThis is not going to be a typical storm,‚Äù Buffalo Mayor Byron Brown said Thursday. ‚ÄúIn fact, this could be a life-threatening storm.‚Äù

About 2,400 flights have been canceled across the US Thursday, according to the flight tracking site FlightAware, snarling air travel amid the busy holiday season. And airlines have canceled more than 2,200 US flights scheduled for Friday.

In South Dakota, a 340-mile stretch of Interstate 90 was closed in both directions Thursday morning, from Rapid City to Sioux Falls, because of blizzard-like conditions, officials said. Near-zero visibility also led to many highway closures between Colorado and Wyoming on Wednesday.

Even Florida won‚Äôt be spared, with residents of the Sunshine State expected to see sudden temperature drops Friday. Some cities in the South ‚Äì including Nashville and Memphis ‚Äì are expected to see snow Thursday.

Flooding, meanwhile, is possible in parts of the Northeast, including Washington and Philadelphia, as rain hits the area Thursday before temperatures plummet overnight and bring a ‚Äúflash freeze.‚Äù

President Joe Biden received a briefing on the weather Thursday morning at the White House, from the National Weather Service and Federal Emergency Management Agency. He encouraged Americans to heed the warnings of local officials and to stay safe in the face of the extreme cold.

‚ÄúThis is really a very serious weather alert here,‚Äù Biden said, adding that the White House has reached out to 26 governors in the affected regions.

What‚Äôs ahead for the bomb cyclone

TOKYO ‚Äî Nintendo is developing a live-action film based on its hit video game "The Legend of Zelda," the Japanese company behind the Super Mario franchise said Wednesday.

The film, with financing from Sony Pictures Entertainment as well as its own investment, will be directed by Wes Ball, the American director of the upcoming "Planet of the Apes" film. It‚Äôs being co-produced by Nintendo and Arad Productions Inc., which is behind the live-action Spider-Man films and headed by Avi Arad.

The move highlights Kyoto-based Nintendo's strategy to leverage various aspects of its business, including theme parks, merchandising and movies, to boost machine and software sales, and vice versa.

That strategy has met success. Its animated film "The Super Mario Bros. Movie," released earlier this year, has raked in more than $1.3 billion and drew nearly 170 million people worldwide.

President Shuntaro Furukawa, briefing reporters online, said the company was pleased with the success of the Super Mario animation film, the first movie of which Nintendo was a direct producer.

The planned release date of the Zelda movie was not announced. Shigeru Miyamoto, the Nintendo executive who has spearheaded the creative innovations at the company for decades, said it will be released only when it‚Äôs ready, while stressing that work on the project has been going on for a decade.

"I realize there are so many Zelda fans, and we cannot betray their expectations. That is a big hurdle. But we are ready," said Miyamoto.

Nintendo reported Tuesday an 18% rise in net profit for its first fiscal half, totaling nearly 271.3 billion yen ($1.8 billion), up from 230 billion yen a year earlier.

Nintendo officials said the success of the Super Mario film has translated into bigger sales for its Switch machines, as well as for game software with Super Mario themes.

The "Super Mario Bros. Wonder" game software, on sale since last month, has been selling at a record brisk pace, they said, totaling 4.3 million games sold in just two weeks.

The latest Zelda game called "Tears of the Kingdom," has been selling well, and Nintendo is hoping the planned movie will benefit from the popularity of the game, which stars a hero and a princess fighting against evil.

The Switch machine, already in its seventh year after its debut, is still doing well in sales, according to Nintendo.

Nintendo is banking on having more people come in contact with its intellectual property through official stores, including pop-ups, theme parks and special events, and now movies.

In the U.S., Nintendo World has opened in Universal Studios in Hollywood, and the company is planning another in Orlando. The area for the park it already has in Japan will grow next year to include a section devoted to Donkey Kong, another Nintendo character, officials said.

Nintendo is also opening a museum devoted to its history and legacy in the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto in March next year.

search_result.title: Is the Gran Turismo movie based on a true story? Yes. Here's a full ...
search_result.text:
While the market dominance of movies plucked from the superhero realm remains undisputed, Hollywood is finding a way to make money off another pop culture staple: video games.

There‚Äôs the recent $1.36 billion haul by ‚ÄúThe Super Mario Bros. Movie,‚Äù and now comes ‚ÄúGran Turismo‚Äù (in theaters now), a live-action film playing off the popularity of the Sony PlayStation auto racing simulator.

While the former was purely a cartoon fantasy, ‚ÄúGran Turismo‚Äù is powered by a true story. But as with most movies, liberties have been taken.

Here‚Äôs a breakdown of fact and fiction with an assist from ‚ÄúGran Turismo‚Äù star Archie Madekwe and the man he‚Äôs playing, video game ace turned-professional race car driver Jann Mardenborough.

Did Nissan and Sony really sponsor a contest to see if a skilled video gamer could race a sports car?

In 2008, Nissan Europe marketing executive Darren Cox (a character based on him named Danny Moore is played by Orlando Bloom) launched the Nissan GT Academy with Sony. The idea was to capitalize on the growing popularity of the racing simulator, whose teenage players would soon become the next generation of automotive buyers.

‚ÄúI thought, what the heck, let me give it a try,‚Äù says Mardenborough, 31. ‚ÄúI had dropped out of university because it didn‚Äôt involve driving race cars and was working at a department store, which was soul-sucking. So this happened at the right place and right time.‚Äù

Did Jann Mardenborough win the first Nissan GT Challenge?

British-born Mardenborough actually won the third incarnation of the GT Academy in 2011, and became its youngest champ at just 19. The winner of that inaugural Nissan GT Challenge was Spain‚Äôs Lucas Ordo√±ez, who raced successfully for a number of years.

Mardenborough says the biggest shock of winning was adjusting to the cutthroat world of racing. ‚ÄúI had the inexperience of youth, didn‚Äôt understand the politics, didn‚Äôt know about self-preservation,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut to leave home to do something that brought me joy was easy.‚Äù

Did Jann Mardenborough really come in third at Le Mans?

In 2013, Mardenborough and two other Nissan racers did place third in the LMP2 class at the iconic 24-hour race in France, which is a thematic high point in ‚ÄúGran Turismo.‚Äù

The real team consisted of Mardenborough; inaugural Gran Turismo contest winner Ordo√±ez; plus one racing veteran who did not come from the video game world, Michael Krumm.

But to make the movie more dramatic, the writers made the three Le Mans winners consist of Mardenborough and two of the fictional runners-up.

The victory still looms large. ‚ÄúTo this day, that (Le Mans) trophy is the only one in my room,‚Äù says Mardenborough, who today races largely in Japan. ‚ÄùBut it‚Äôs for third place. I feel there‚Äôs still unfinished business there. I‚Äôd still love to win it.‚Äù

Did Jann Mardenborough almost die in a crash in Germany?

In 2015, a Nissan GT3 sportscar driven by Mardenborough got airborne and left the notoriously difficult and deadly N√ºrburgring track in Germany. A spectator died, and the driver was hospitalized.

‚ÄúBecause it was all real, and someone died, we made sure the movie is very true to life in all the details,‚Äù says Mardenborough. ‚ÄúIt was a big turning point for my career, where it could have all ended, but didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Did Archie Madekwe do his own stunt driving in ‚ÄòGran Turismo‚Äô?

Mardenborough was called in to do the racing scenes for the movie, which says ‚Äúopened me up to a how movies are made, which is thrilling.‚Äù

Madekwe had only recently received his driver‚Äôs license and got a crash course in track driving with a professional. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one of the hardest things I‚Äôve ever done, and honestly, I often would have to kind of throw up in the middle of shooting some of those scenes, the G-forces were that severe on my body,‚Äù says the 28-year-old actor. ‚ÄúBut doing that made me appreciate what drivers do. One mistake and things can go really wrong. There‚Äôs no reset button.‚Äù

Was Jann Mardenborough‚Äôs father really a soccer player?

He's the son of British soccer player Steve Mardenborough, who played for a range of clubs. ‚ÄúGran Turismo‚Äù mines the often-tense relationship between Jann and his father (played by Djimon Hounsou) for some of its most powerful scenes.

Mardenborough says the tension wasn't contrived. When he announced to his father and soccer-crazed brother that he was applying for the GT Academy, ‚Äúmy father laughed, and they both just kept watching. My mother thought it was fantastic.‚Äù

Why does the actress playing Jann‚Äôs mother look familiar?

Lesley Mardenborough is played by Spice Girl Geri Halliwell, who will be recognized by fans of the Netflix Formula 1 racing docuseries ‚ÄúDrive to Survive.‚Äù

Halliwell has a true motorsports connection. She's married to Christian Horner, one of series' stars and team principal for the currently dominant F1 team, Red Bull. He and Halliwell make frequent appearances in the series, both at the track and at their home in rural England.

What cars do Jann Mardenborough and Archie Madekwe drive for real?

Mardenborough cherishes his 1990s dream car that he was finally able to afford, a 1995 Ferrari 456 GT in blue with cream leather. It‚Äôs a two-door car, but rare for a Ferrari in that it has back seats. ‚ÄúI like to joke that one day when I have a wife and family, I‚Äôll be able to tell them, look, it fits all of us, no need to sell it,‚Äù he says.

Madekwe is still shopping for his first vehicle. While he likes the Nissan GT-R, a pivotal ‚ÄúGran Turismo‚Äù scene finds him and crew chief Jack Salter (a composite character played by David Harbour) returning to the N√ºrburgring in an exotic Porsche 911 GT3 RS. ‚ÄúGetting into that car, I thought, OK, wow, now I get it,‚Äù Madekwe says. ‚ÄúThat car made me a car fan.‚Äù

Will Ferrell is slated to star as John Madden in an upcoming movie about the Hall of Fame coach and broadcaster who also became famous for the football video game that bears his name, according to a Deadline report.

The movie, called "Madden," will be produced by Amazon and MGM studios and directed by David O'Russell, a five-time Academy Award nominee, Deadline reports. The movie will be based on a Black List script by Cambron Clark, according to Deadline. This film is independent of another project about Madden's life that is reportedly in the works with Tom Brady as executive producer.

There is no indication when filming on "Madden" will start or when the movie will be released.

Ferrell has a long personal history with sports. The actor studied sports information at Southern California with hopes of becoming a sports broadcaster. He has made numerous appearances for Trojans football games and events. He also has starred in an array of sports movies.

DO YOU LIKE FOOTBALL? Then you'll enjoy getting our NFL newsletter delivered to your inbox

NFL STATS CENTRAL: The latest NFL scores, schedules, odds, stats and more.

Adding to John Madden's legacy

Clearly there is plenty of material to delve into in a feature film about the man whose career involved coaching one of the NFL's most notorious teams, thriving as a broadcasting and commercial star, and being the creative force behind a highly successful video game.

Madden's career in football already has been thoroughly reviewed in documentaries. The Hall of Fame coach-turned-broadcaster's life was explored in the "All Madden" documentary that originally aired on Christmas Day 2021, just three days before the football icon died at the age of 85. search_result.title: 'Sonic the Hedgehog' movie redesign: How backlash made Sonic ...
search_result.text:
Sonic the Hedgehog, the beloved Sega video-game character with lightning speed, had to survive his harshest foe to make it to the big screen: Twitter.

Like the very blue Genie in "Aladdin" and the freaky felines of "Cats," Sonic sped right into a social media backlash of loathing from fans when the too-realistic computer-generated creation (with conspicuously human teeth) was unveiled in 2019's first trailer.

Remarkably, director Jeff Fowler and Paramount Studios heard the criticism, delayed the film's release and retooled the pivotal character. The revised Sonic (voiced by Ben Schwartz) reappeared in a November trailer to (gasp!) acclaim and will officially arrive in theaters Friday alongside humans Jim Carrey as the villainous Dr. Robotnik and James Marsden as Sonic's small-town cop sidekick.

"This is a big deal. 'Sonic' filmmakers learned you have to appease the hardcore fans," says Jeff Bock, senior box-office analyst for Exhibitor Relations. "The fans said, 'This is not the Sonic we know,' and amazingly, Paramount redid it. It looks like this will pay off as 'Sonic' is a near lock to win the weekend box office. This is the anti-'Cats' scenario."

Boom! 'Sonic the Hedgehog':Defies video-game odds with a record $57M box office

Fans revolt over 'Sonic the Hedgehog':All anyone could see were those too-human teeth in the first trailer

The very public criticism has been painful but fruitful for the director.

"I would not wish this experience necessarily on anyone, even though, at the end of the day, I really love that we engaged the fan base. They felt heard by our response," Fowler says. "Honest, one of my biggest sources of pride from this whole process was that the fans were able to be involved in this movie. They helped get us where this needed to be."

Fowler, director of the Oscar-nominated animated short "Gopher Broke," was a fan of the "Sonic" video games, which have developed a passionate global following since their origins in 1991's Sega Genesis.

But unlike ABC's "Sonic the Hedgehog" series (1993-94) and other TV projects that followed, Fowler wanted to bring Sonic's simple blockhead-cartoon design into a live-action drama. He knew this would be difficult.

"When I had my first meeting about this movie, if you'd asked me the biggest challenge, I would have said figuring out how to interpret Sonic's design for a realistic setting, standing next to human characters," Fowler says. "That was always going to be the trick."

Fowler and the visual effects team created a Sonic with realistic features ‚Äì eerily humanlike teeth, fingers, limbs and spiky fur, fans insisted. They made it very clear it was too real, with Twitter reviews that called the creation "an abomination."

The immediate takeaway was obvious.

"We just went too far," Fowler says. "There was just too much realism. We just lost what it was that fans loved about the character."

Despite the Twitter pile-on, there was no time to wallow.

"I allowed myself about five to 10 minutes of pity and feeling sorry for myself," says Fowler, who tweeted out a message to fans on May 2 with the hashtag #gottafixfast. "It was just such an overwhelming response that it was important to me that (outreach) happen very quickly."

Paramount pushed back the release date three months to February, and the filmmakers dove into redesigning Sonic.

"You have to figure out a way to work through it and every second counts. We knew that there was a way to solve this if we brought the right people together and did the right adjustments," Fowler says. "There was some speculation that we had to redo the whole movie. That was very erroneous.

"Even though redesigning your main character at the point we were at was not necessarily ideal."

Fowler estimates two months were devoted to the overhaul and re-creation of the character to more closely resemble the video game ‚Äì with larger eyes, less obvious teeth, bouncier fur and a softer nose.

"It was really just pulling back on the realism but keeping that level of detail we felt the film needed for a vibrant, fully realized character," he says.

Schwartz got a "sneak peek" at the new Sonic before the second trailer, and the voice actor's enthusiastic response was a relief to Fowler. But there was clearly suspense before going public.

To his relief, this time Twitter was positive. "Just because you listened to criticism of the original trailer and put in all that work to make the improvements. I‚Äôll reward that! Count me in for opening weekend," wrote Twitter user @aaronthew.

"The second time is a charm," Fowler says.

With that hurdle overcome, Fowler is now looking ahead to whether "Sonic the Hedgehog" will be successful enough for a sequel, even a franchise, adding more characters from the video games like fox sidekick Tails and Knuckles the Echidna.

"There are so many more great characters to bring into the story if we're able," Fowler says. "Nothing would bring me more happiness than getting another shot to tell more stories. Knock on wood, we would love to do more with the Sonic universe."

He's already learned the most important design lesson, the hard way.

"We have cracked the code," Fowler says. "So now we have a guide to figuring out the rest of the characters."

search_result.title: Friday the 13th video game maker Gun Interactive based in Kentucky
search_result.text:
As a student at the University of Kentucky, it didn't matter if Wes Keltner was on campus, downtown, or at a bar, the only thing he could think about was the video game industry.

Keltner, a native of Campbellsville, dreamed of working in the video game industry but believed it meant he'd need to leave his home state of Kentucky and head west to California.

"I couldn't look around me and know [the video game industry] could be done here" at the time, Keltner said. "I wanted to see myself in a business or in an idea and that was not available to me when I was in school [from 2001-2005]. There was nothing that was about video games."

In 2010, after five years of video game consulting work where companies like Electronic Arts, Activision and Microsoft, would fly Keltner out to play their games and critique them, he decided he would be the one to bring the video game industry to Kentucky. So he founded Gun Interactive, an indie video game design studio with a focus on the horror genre.

The 11-person company based in Lexington is best known for making the wildly-popular M-rated "Friday the 13th: The Game," based on the 1980 film starring actor Kane Hodder as Jason Voorhees, who terrorizes the teenagers of Camp Crystal Lake.

To date, the game has over 13 million registered players.

You may likeHow a $15M gift to Norton may very well transform diabetes care in Kentucky

"I didn't want to leave (Lexington), and I thought if I can pull this off here, I can do it anywhere," Keltner, the 43-year-old CEO and President of Gun Interactive, told the Courier Journal. "It was kind of like choosing to make games on hard mode because there's not a lot of other game studios around here."

Keltner combined his love for classic horror films and his passion for video games to create a new genre of games, a new style of play, and prove Kentucky can produce globally known video games.

Modeling interactive video games off 'Friday the 13th,' more horror films

Gun Interactive's niche and focus lie in nostalgic horror films.

"I look at stuff that's usually at least 30 years old," Keltner said.

The video game studio is currently working on turning the 1974 "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" film into a video game that has a targeted 2023 release date. It will be the studio's fifth game produced in 12 years.

To enhance the creative video game design process and make sure all employees understand the details of the film, Keltner and his team have the film on in the background all the time and "re-watch the film twice a day."

As a company, Gun Interactive, Gun for short, is obsessed with details. While creating "Friday the 13th: The Game," they brought in actors from the film, including Hodder, to model their character's movements. They also met with the film's director of cinematography to ensure the authenticity of the game matched the film.

"When you have the guy that's played Jason, and he's in there doing, crazy kills, it looks accurate," Keltner said. "If you were to go watch the movie, and then look at the game, Jason moves just like the Jason does in the movie ‚Ä¶ it's because it's the same guy."

Working on a "Friday the 13th" video game, modeled after the cult-favorite movie, wasn't an accident. After creating their first two games, a mobile-only military game, and a small horror game, Keltner immediately started writing a design for a game he planned to call "Summer Camp." After releasing some early sketches of the game design, which paid homage to slasher films, the rights holders to "Friday the 13th" contacted Keltner asking to turn the film into a game.

You may likeJefferson County ranks in top 3 wealthiest counties across Kentucky. See how it stacks up

Keltner said his company has become well enough known that "Hollywood comes to us." But the crew at Gun Interactive is highly selective on which projects they choose to take on. The time commitment to make a game from start to finish takes about three years.

In its 12-year tenure, Gun Interactive has turned down at least 12 other projects.

‚ÄúIt's a big time investment. It's a big money investment," Keltner said. "And just creatively, we know that's the only thing we're going to be doing."

"Friday the 13th: The Game" launched in 2017 and can be found digitally on the Xbox or PlayStation store, the Nintendo Switch or Steam, a PC gaming software. The game can also be purchased at stores like Best Buy and Walmart.

Currently, the company plans to have ‚ÄúThe Texas Chainsaw Massacre‚Äù available on PC, on eighth and ninth generation Xbox and PlayStation consoles, and in stores. The game will not be available on Nintendo Switch. The newest game is expected to cost between $30-$40.

Keltner and his team created "Friday the 13th: The Game" on a budget of less than $10 million, a fraction of what major video game studios spend on game creation.

"We made 'Friday the 13th' on a shoestring budget," Keltner said. "Which is kind of ironic, because the first film was also made on a shoestring budget."

Keltner said the average budget to bring a game to market is between $30 and $50 million and that doesn't include the cost for live operations, a period of time where teams work to fix any bugs or generate new content after release.

‚ÄúWe're scrappy," Keltner said of Gun. "We try to make the most with the smallest amount of money."

More:Want to break into Kentucky's growing video game industry? Here are 3 ways to get involved

How Gun developed a new asymmetrical multiplayer gaming genre

The release of "Friday the 13th: The Game" also introduced the world to a new gaming genre ‚Äï the asymmetrical multiplayer horror game. Unlike games like "Call of Duty," where all players can have weapons and equal abilities, in an asymmetrical multiplayer game, players are not all equal. Some players, for example, are Jason Voorhees who has special abilities and others are camp counselors.

"Those games didn't really exist much before we came to the market," Keltner said. "We helped co-invent an entirely new gaming genre."

And even though Gun Interactive has helped pave new ground for the video game industry, Keltner said his company ‚Äúflies under the radar," and he sometimes struggles with attracting new talent when working in an industry primarily located on the other side of the country.

Louisville restuarants:These 5 restaurants are set to open in October in the Louisville area

"It's a pretty big ask, whenever you try to get someone to pack up and move from some other state, but we've managed to do it and we've got members on our team that packed up (and) left their state to come here," Keltner said.

Jonathan Hale, a professor of art and digital media at the University of Pikeville, said gaming is one of the largest industries in the world and is very profitable. He believes having studios like Gun in the state allow the industry to continue to grow and provides opportunities for more people to join the video game world.

"Kentucky needs to attract studios and get some of that money coming into the state," Hale said. "We need to train students to be able to get into this highly lucrative field."

That "under the radar" approach of Gun is partly by design. The video game industry has a dark side, Keltner said. Gamers have been known to make threats against companies like Gun after having a feature of a game changed or discontinued.

"It can be a very toxic and sometimes sort of scary job to have," Keltner said.

The FBI has even been involved a few times after Keltner‚Äôs company received shooting or death threats.

"We take every one of those threats very seriously, they get turned over to the feds. And then those people get investigated pretty quickly. So, it's never a smart thing to do," Keltner said.

A new chapter for Kentucky's growing video game industry

As a state, Kentucky has opened its arms to the small business. Every investment dollar that has been put into Gun Interactive has come from Kentucky, with the majority of investors coming from the Louisville and Lexington area, Keltner said.

"We've never gone to California and met with venture capitalists," Keltner said.

And he plans to keep it that way. For the Kentucky-grown Keltner, keeping investment dollars local has shown him that his home state believes in his dream of bringing the video game industry to Kentucky.

"I owe a lot to those people," Keltner said.

You may likeBrown-Forman moves into the rum market with purchase of premium spirits brand

As a pioneer of the industry in this state, Keltner has made it his personal mission to help the video gaming industry here grow. He has worked his connections at Sony and Microsoft to help smaller studios promote and grow their games and reach.

"There's not many of us," Keltner said. "Part of me feels almost responsible for pushing that industry here."

He currently sits on the board of the Eastern Kentucky University gaming institute and at one point, was involved in casual conversation with the University of Kentucky's eSports Program.

Hale, a former adjunct professor at EKU for six years who was involved with the gaming institute, has seen the impact Keltner's studio has on students interested in gaming.

"Wes is very passionate about making games and Kentucky ... He is also very open to talking to students and helping with internships," Hale said. "Being able to take students to studios and talk to game (developers) in person is priceless."

As Keltner continues to trailblaze the path to video game development in Kentucky, he always remembers being that young college student searching for his place.

"If anyone says anything about video games, I‚Äôll be there," Keltner said. "I want the 19-year-old version of me that's walking around campus to hear they made 'Friday the 13th' in Lexington ‚Ä¶ I want them to know, you could do this too. You could start something here."

Video-game movies may be Hollywood's Achilles heel.

The film industry has been churning out adaptations of games like ‚ÄúWorld of Warcraft‚Äù and ‚ÄúAssassin's Creed‚Äù for years, but there's something about turning these popular games into two-hour narratives that almost always fails. The things that often make video games successful ‚Äì generic characters, simple plots, lots of violence ‚Äì often make movies dull and frustrating. And yet, filmmakers keep trying, this week with "Uncharted" (in theaters now).

But a few films stand out from the pack. We rounded up the best video-game films available to rent or stream.

Review:Tom Holland's action-packed 'Uncharted' maps out a forgettable Indiana Jones knockoff

If you dig Indiana Jones-y action: 'Uncharted'

"Spider-Man: No Way Home" star Tom Holland plays baby-faced fortune hunter Nathan Drake in the adventure based on the popular PlayStation series. Nate seeks a lost treasure and faces crazy obstacles (such as free-falling on a car out of a cargo plane) alongside his wisecracking, untrustworthy partner Sully (Mark Wahlberg).

If you like fuzzy cartoon speedsters: 'Sonic the Hedgehog'

Mixing live action with animation, the 2020 comedy was a huge hit with all ages, mainly thanks to the fleet-footed, sneaker-clad title character voiced by Ben Schwartz. Also helping: Jim Carrey back to his over-the-top self as Sonic's mustache-twirling arch nemesis, Dr. Robotnik.

Where to watch: Paramount+

If you love Angelina Jolie: ‚ÄòLara Croft: Tomb Raider‚Äô

Alicia Vikander did her best in a poorly constructed film in the 2018 ‚ÄúTomb Raider‚Äù adaptation, but there's no replacing Jolie's version of the character, which became a pop-culture touchstone in the early 2000s. Sure, the movie is hammy and the costume is, shall we say, less than practical, but Jolie is a magnetic presence and sells every inch of the two movies.

Where to watch: On-demand platforms including Apple TV and Amazon Prime

If you want a marathon: The ‚ÄòResident Evil‚Äô franchise

‚ÄúResident Evil‚Äù is arguably the most successful video-game adaptation franchise, spawning seven sci-fi horror movies and turning Milla Jovovich into a star. The original 2001 film feels almost tame compared with the wild heights the later films would reach (in both story and CGI), while the 2021 movie "Welcome to Raccoon City" rebooted the series for a new generation.

Where to watch: On-demand platforms including Apple TV and Vudu

If you like great martial arts: ‚ÄòMortal Kombat‚Äô

These films don't try to be more than the premise of the super-popular game: A group of different fighters battling for the fate of the world. The first 1995 film was a simple yet strong effort, and the 2021 reboot upped the fantasy element with a bunch of over-the-top characters.

Where to watch: HBO Max

If you want to feel like you're watching a video game: ‚ÄòDoom‚Äô

There's no mistaking this 2005 film for anything but a video-game adaptation. It revels in using aspects of video-game storytelling in its visuals, including a scene that feels like a first-person shooter game. It also gets bonus points for being one of Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson's first feature films.

Where to watch: HBO Max

search_result.text:
Sarah Whitten

CNBC

As ‚ÄúAvengers: Endgame‚Äù has raced its way to and beyond the highest-grossing film record held by ‚ÄúAvatar,‚Äù questions have arisen about how Hollywood determines what movie is considered the biggest earner.

After all, ‚ÄúAvatar‚Äù was released in 2009, so wouldn‚Äôt a fairer comparison to 2019's ‚ÄúEndgame‚Äù be adjusted for inflation?

Well, it‚Äôs not that simple.

There‚Äôs a reason the film industry doesn‚Äôt measure the success of modern movies against those of the past ‚Äì movie ticket inflation isn‚Äôt an exact science. There are so many factors behind what makes a movie a box-office success and those factors have changed since the earliest days of cinema.

From Hollywood to Seoul:How #MeToo is upending Asian entertainment industries

Disney bought Marvel for $4 billion:It‚Äôs made over $18 billion since

For one, consumers have many more choices of what to spend their money on when it comes to entertainment. Even if you exclude sporting events, concerts and at-home entertainment such as streaming services and video games, just the sheer number of options of what movie to see in theaters is so much larger than 50 years ago.

For that reason, a film like ‚ÄúGone With the Wind‚Äù sold more than 200 million tickets over the course of its initial release and additional seven re-releases in the U.S. For comparison, Disney‚Äôs ‚ÄúEndgame‚Äù sold around 94.8 million tickets domestically since its release in April.

The content of movies has also changed drastically. Three-hour dramas about the lives of Southerners during the Civil War wouldn‚Äôt be as popular in 2019 as they were in, say, 1939. So, it would be difficult to say with certainty that a film that thrived decades ago would still do so today.

Another major reason that Hollywood doesn‚Äôt adjust for inflation is the number of foreign markets films are now released in. Analysts would have to dive into each global market to determine the inflation rate in each country, a task that is nearly impossible considering most films are released in more than 100 markets during their initial run.

Still, it‚Äôs an interesting exercise. So, CNBC contacted Comscore, a media measurement and analytics company, to work out how an adjusted figure could be determined. Paul Dergarabedian and his team devised a method wherein they divided the average ticket price for the year a film was released into the film‚Äôs gross to determine the estimated number of tickets the film would have sold. Of course, this gets tricky, especially considering so many high-grossing films are re-released long after their initial debut.

For instance, ‚ÄúSnow White and the Seven Dwarfs‚Äù was released in theaters in 1937, 1983, 1987 and 1993. So for these films, Comscore used the average ticket price for each of those different years and divided them into the gross for each re-release.

To be sure, this isn‚Äôt a perfect method. Average ticket prices are just that, an average. There‚Äôs no way to break down the price of IMAX screenings and 3D screenings, or pricing based on region.

Not to mention, ticket prices vary by year. In 2017, the average ticket price was $8.97. In 2018, it was $9.11. This year, it is $9.01. So if this adjustment had been done last year, the numbers would have been significantly higher.

That being said, here are the top 10 highest-grossing films in the U.S. if Hollywood did adjust the box office, based on modern ticket prices:

10. 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs' (1937)

Estimated admissions: 109 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $982 million

Since 1937, ‚ÄúSnow White and the Seven Dwarfs‚Äù has garnered around $184.9 million at the domestic box office. The film was the first full-length animated feature from Disney.

The film has been re-released at least three times and made more money from those re-releases than it did from its initial 1937 release.

Comscore determined that since its debut, around 109 million tickets have been sold. At today‚Äôs average ticket price, the film would have made nearly $1 billion in the U.S.

9. 'The Exorcist' (1973)

Estimated admissions: 116.5 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.04 billion

One of only six horror films to be nominated for the Academy Award for best picture, ‚ÄúThe Exorcist‚Äù has hauled in more than $232.9 million since its 1973 debut.

The film made the bulk of its money during its initial release. It was brought back to theaters in 2000 and 2010 with extended scenes.

Adjusted for today‚Äôs ticket prices, ‚ÄúThe Exorcist,‚Äù which sold an estimated 116.5 million tickets, would have made around $1.04 billion.

8. 'Doctor Zhivago (1965)

Estimated admissions: 124.6 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.12 billion

Released only in 1965, ‚ÄúDoctor Zhivago‚Äù earned $112.1 million during its run in theaters and won five Academy Awards.

It‚Äôs estimated that around 124.6 million tickets were sold for the film. Adjusted for today‚Äôs ticket prices, that would be around $1.12 billion at the box office.

7. 'Jaws' (1975)

Estimated admissions: 128 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.15 billion

Steven Spielberg‚Äôs ‚ÄúJaws‚Äù was released in theaters in 1975 and earned $260 million. Like ‚ÄúThe Exorcist,‚Äù it is one of six horror movies to be nominated for best picture. It did not win the award, however.

Comscore estimates that around 128 million tickets were sold during the film‚Äôs run. Adjusted for today‚Äôs ticket prices, the film would have earned around $1.15 billion at the box office.

6. 'The Ten Commandments' (1956)

Estimated admissions: 131 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.18 billion

The 3-hour-and-40-minute feature debuted in 1956 and earned $65.5 million.

The iconic film, which featured famed actors Charlton Heston as Moses and Yul Brynner as Rameses II, sold an estimated 131 million tickets during its run. Adjusted for today‚Äôs ticket prices, the film would have earned around $1.18 billion at the U.S. box office.

5. 'Titanic' (1997)

Estimated admissions: 143.5 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.29 billion

‚ÄúTitanic‚Äù is regarded as one of the best films in industry history and is also one of the highest-grossing. Without adjusting for inflation, James Cameron‚Äôs masterpiece is the sixth highest-grossing film in the U.S. and the third-highest grossing film globally.

The film has been re-released twice in addition to its initial run, once in 3D and once to celebrate its 20th anniversary. During those runs, the film earned $658.6 million domestically.

It‚Äôs estimated that ‚ÄúTitanic‚Äù sold around 143.5 million tickets. Adjusted for today‚Äôs ticket prices, the film would have earned around $1.29 billion at the U.S. box office.

4. 'E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial' (1982)

Estimated admissions: 147.9 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.33 billion

The four-time Academy Award-winning ‚ÄúE.T.‚Äù hauled in $434.9 million since it was first released in 1982. Although it was re-released twice, once in 1985 and once in 2002, the film made the bulk of its earnings during its debut.

‚ÄúE.T.‚Äù sold an estimated 147.9 million tickets, which translated to around $1.33 billion in ticket sales using today‚Äôs average ticket price.

3. 'The Sound of Music' (1965)

Estimated admissions: 157.2 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.41 billion

‚ÄúThe Sound of Music‚Äù was released twice in theaters. Once was its 1965 debut, where it made the bulk of its $158.8 million haul in the U.S., the other was a 2018 re-release.

Comscore estimated that the film, which won five Academy Awards, sold around 157.2 million tickets. That is around $1.41 billion when adjusted for today‚Äôs ticket prices.

2. 'Star Wars' (1977)

Estimated admissions: 178.1 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.6 billion

1977‚Ä≤s blockbuster ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù has been reissued at least twice since its initial debut and has earned $460.9 million at the U.S. box office.

In the last four decades, the film has sold an estimated 178.1 million tickets, which equates to around $1.6 billion at the modern domestic box office.

1. 'Gone With the Wind' (1939)

Estimated admissions: 201 million tickets

Estimated adjusted gross: $1.81 billion

‚ÄúGone With the Wind‚Äù has been re-released at least seven times since its initial debut in 1939, Comscore said. During that time, it has grossed around $203 million.

However, its popularity has resulted in more than 201 million tickets being sold in the last 80 years. If all of those tickets had been bought today, the film would have grossed around $1.8 billion at the domestic box office.

search_result.text:
In the last 10 years, Jason Aldean has sold more than 10 million concert tickets, 18 million albums, racked up 4 billion digital streams and is the RIAA‚Äôs top digital male country artist of all time. He‚Äôs charted 22 No. 1 songs and won 14 Academy of Country Music Awards, including three consecutive trophies for Entertainer of the Year.

However, he still wasn‚Äôt expecting his latest accolade ‚Äì The ACM Dick Clark Artist of the Decade. When Aldean is bestowed with the honor Sunday during the 54th ACM Awards, he‚Äôll be in rarefied air ‚Äì only George Strait (2008), Garth Brooks (1998), Alabama (1988), Loretta Lynn (1979) and Marty Robbins (1969) have won the award.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm kind of a little surprised,‚Äù Aldean admitted. ‚ÄúI guess more so because this isn‚Äôt something they give out every year, so it wasn‚Äôt even on my radar. I look at all the artists out there, and I feel like a lot of them have had a pretty great decade so to be the one that everyone voted for, that is pretty special. I‚Äôm proud, excited and pretty blown away, a lot of different things.‚Äù

Aldean will perform with Florida Georgia Line as well as sing a medley of his hits during the 54th ACM Awards, which will air live from MGM Grand‚Äôs Garden Arena 7 p.m. Sunday on CBS. He‚Äôs the first artist to receive the ACM Dick Clark Artist of the Decade Award since it was posthumously named after the awards show‚Äôs former host and longtime producer Dick Clark.

‚ÄúFor me, the Artist of the Decade Award is so special because as the name says ... it really takes a snapshot of who has been the biggest artist in the past 10 years,‚Äù Dick Clark‚Äôs son and current ACM Awards producer RAC Clark said. ‚ÄúChanging the name embraces my father‚Äôs participation in the ACM Awards. He was there for decades to help nurture it and take it along from being a late-night television show and being the host of it to getting it on NBC and then CBS. It just started as a little awards ceremony in the middle of Hollywood.‚Äù

A decade of Jason Aldean

Aldean‚Äôs decade of radio domination started in 2009 with the release of his ‚ÄúWide Open‚Äù album. While the Georgia native had had previous hits including ‚ÄúAmarillo Sky,‚Äù ‚ÄúLaughed Until We Cried‚Äù and ‚ÄúJohnny Cash,‚Äù ‚ÄúWide Open‚Äù was home to ‚ÄúBig Green Tractor,‚Äù which is still Aldean‚Äôs longest-running No. 1 hit. The song‚Äôs success came as a surprise to the singer and he said he knew it was next level when he started hearing people use the suggestive track as their ring tone. His fast-talking smash ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs Country‚Äù was from the same album and pushed the envelope in a different direction, giving fans the biggest nod at what was coming next ‚Äì ‚ÄúMy Kinda Party.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat was the start of the decade for me and then with that next album, everything went nuts,‚Äù he said, referencing ‚ÄúMy Kinda Party,‚Äù which is also home to ‚ÄúDirt Road Anthem.‚Äù ‚ÄúAt that point, I think it was a hang-on-for-the-ride sort of deal. I just think back to going from being an opening act for people on the road to selling out stadiums. I wanted to sell out a club, you know what I mean? A stadium was really reaching.‚Äù

But he did sell out stadiums. Aldean packed UGA‚Äôs Sanford Stadium, Fenway Park, Wrigley Field, AT&T Stadium and Gillette Stadium among others.

He‚Äôs also quick to point out ‚Äì and take blame ‚Äì for the fact that his career path hasn‚Äôt been smooth. Choices he made in his personal life sometimes flung his name into headlines he‚Äôd rather forget. And when he was on stage during the Las Vegas shooting in 2017 that left 58 people dead, his life changed again. Aldean will never forget what happened that night, but he forged ahead to play shows and make new music for country fans.

‚ÄúWhen things hit like that, it‚Äôs life-altering,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAs the artist, we‚Äôre just trying to navigate the road. A lot of ways I feel like I‚Äôve grown up in this business and people have seen it first-hand.‚Äù

Over the course of his career, Aldean said he‚Äôs learned that making compelling music trumps everything. Nowadays, every mistake ends up on social media until someone else makes a bigger faux pas, he explained. But once his album is out, he said the unimportant stuff falls away.

‚ÄúThat was always my goal, to stay focused on what I do,‚Äù Aldean said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt change what I can‚Äôt change, but I can stay focused on making my records.‚Äù

He's proud of his work ‚Äì admittedly more so of some songs than others. Aldean loved ‚ÄúTattoos on This Town‚Äù and ‚ÄúMy Kinda Party,‚Äù but said his rap-infused ‚ÄúDirt Road Anthem‚Äù initially made him nervous.

More:ACM Awards: Who will (and who should) win

More:Brandi Carlile abandoned country music out of fear. Now in its embrace, 'no one has hurt me yet.'

‚ÄúI remember sitting in the studio with (producer Michael Knox) going, ‚ÄòMan, if we don‚Äôt do this just right ‚Ä¶ it could be huge, or it could be a disaster,‚Äù Aldean said. ‚ÄúIt was never a matter of, ‚ÄòWere we going to cut it?‚Äô But, it was, ‚ÄòHow do we make this work?‚Äô‚Äù

With more than 4 million copies sold since 2010, ‚ÄúDirt Road Anthem‚Äù is certified quadruple platinum.

‚ÄúMy Kinda Party‚Äù and ‚ÄúNight Train,‚Äù Aldean said represent the best albums he can make. He feels the same way about 99 percent of his recent ‚ÄúRearview Town‚Äù and he said the album on which he‚Äôs currently working is shaping up to be just as strong.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to just have a few songs that are going to be a single and everything else is just alright,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI never know what the singles or going to be so if I‚Äôm going to cut 15 songs, I want 15 songs that I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòAny of these could be singles.‚Äô‚Äù

The recording process takes longer, he said, but it‚Äôs worth it.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like everything we learned in the first part of my career we‚Äôre putting to use now,‚Äù Aldean explained. ‚ÄúWe dialed everything that we do in more so than we have before.‚Äù

search_result.title: CMA Awards 2019: 9 big moments from the show
search_result.text:
The 53rd annual CMA Awards delivered three hours' worth of inspiring collaborations, tearful tributes, powerful statements and thrilling wins Wednesday night.

From a massive opening number to the battle for the top prize, these were the biggest moments of "country music's biggest night."

A monumental opening

The CMAs promised to open the show with an ode to women. And it delivered with ‚Äî in the words of Gretchen Wilson ‚Äî one "epic celebration." The night kicked off with its powerhouse hosts, Dolly Parton, Carrie Underwood and Reba McEntire, kicking into a rendition of "Those Memories of You" before an onslaught of country music's leading women past and present.

CMA Awards 2019:How did Dolly Parton, Reba McEntire and Carrie Underwood do as hosts?

Tanya Tucker dug into classic "Delta Dawn," Gretchen Wilson kicked out "Redneck Woman," the Highwomen paid tribute to Tammy Wynette with "Your Good Girl's Gonna Go Bad" ... and that's not half of what viewers saw.

"What a way to kick off country music‚Äôs biggest night!" Underwood declared in the opening monologue.

A female fiddler makes history

Jenee Fleenor ‚Äî longtime fiddle player for Blake Shelton and "The Voice" house band ‚Äî can add an unprecedented line to her resume: first-ever woman to win a CMA Award for Musician of the Year.

She competed in the category with Mac McAnally, Paul Franklin, Ilya Toshinsky and Derek Wells.

Fleenor was the first female nominated for the category, which the Country Music Association created in 1988.

"I just broke down in tears," she told The Tennessean on CMA nomination day. "It's been a dream of mine since I knew what the CMAs were, to be named with all of my peers and heroes."

A few hours after her win, Fleenor was onstage with Shelton, performing his Single of the Year winner, ‚ÄúGod‚Äôs Country.‚Äù Shelton ‚Äî a vocal booster of Fleenor‚Äôs talents ‚Äî brought her to center stage for a solo, and the pair hugged at the end of the song.

CMA Awards 2019:List of winners

Ashley McBryde 'steps up'

Acclaimed singer-songwriter Ashley McBryde beat out some tough competition to be named New Artist of the Year at Wednesday's CMA Awards, thanks to her debut album, "Girl Going Nowhere," and its powerful title track.

The spark for the song came from an algebra teacher who scoffed at McBryde's dream of moving to Nashville to write songs. But when she accepted the award, she opted to remember the words of encouragement she'd received on her way up.

"I once had the pleasure of playing a tribute show for Mr. John Prine, and the next day he shook my hand and he said, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre real good. You‚Äôre no Reba, but you're real good,' " McBryde said, and the crowd laughed.

"I cherish those little moments that are like that ‚Äî that are truth and guidance from voices that we respect and admire. And I‚Äôm thankful for that, and for this, and for the opportunity to step up."

Dolly sings faith

It wouldn't be a night with Dolly Parton at the CMA Awards if she just co-hosted and opened the show, right?

The country music icon teamed with a pair of standout Christian acts ‚Äî Grammy Award-winning duo for KING & Country and solo artist Zach Williams ‚Äî for a powerhouse performance Wednesday night at Bridgestone Arena.

Parton joined for KING & COUNTRY on a remix of the band's Dove Award-winning song "God Only Knows" and Williams on his October single, "There Was Jesus." She closed the performance with a solo performance of "Faith," a 2019 collaboration with Swedish duo Galantis.

Maren Morris remembers late producer

Maren Morris' stellar sophomore effort, "Girl," was named Album of the Year at the CMA Awards, and the moment was bittersweet for the 29-year-old country star.

The majority of "Girl," like her debut, "Hero," before it, was produced by late songwriter and producer Michael James Ryan ‚Äî known professionally as Busbee ‚Äî who died in September at age 43.

"I would be really remiss if I didn't mention a huge facet of why this album sounds the way it does," Morris said as she accepted the award.

"And we miss him so dearly. He texted me the morning that we got the nomination for Album of the Year this year, and we were so excited. And that's our friend Busbee. His wife, Jess, is here tonight, and she looks so beautiful. Thank you for sharing your husband with us once a month. And my heart just goes out to you and your beautiful daughters. I hope when they listen to this record or any of the songs that he made ‚Äî that made us all better ‚Äî they know how amazing their father was."

Kristofferson honored with rocking 'Me and Bobby McGee'

Kris Kristofferson couldn't make it to Nashville on Wednesday night, but that didn't stop Sheryl Crow and Dierks Bentley from leading a ripping country-rock collaboration in honor of the iconic songwriter.

Bentley and Crow performed famed Kristofferson song "Me and Bobby McGee" alongside Eagles guitarist Joe Walsh, Chris Janson and John Osborne of Brothers Osborne.

"This one‚Äôs for you, Kris," Bentley exclaimed, kicking into a familiar first verse that sets the scene of being "busted flat in Baton Rouge, waitin' for a train."

The Country Music Association honored Kristofferson with the Willie Nelson Lifetime Achievement Award on Wednesday at the annual CMAs. He wasn't in attendance due to a previously booked gig on his touring schedule in Davenport, Iowa.

Kacey and Willie's 'Rainbow Connection'

Kacey Musgraves' year of the rainbow continued Wednesday night with a little help from Willie Nelson.

The extravagant modern star joined forces at the CMA Awards in Nashville with the country legend for a poignant performance of "Rainbow Connection," a song made famous by Kermit the Frog (yes, seriously).

Musgraves and Nelson ‚Äî who previously collaborated on Musgraves' 2015 album "Pageant Material" and holiday record "A Very Kacey Christmas" ‚Äî exchanged verses, the 86-year-old crooning in his familiar drawl.

"Someday we‚Äôll find it, the rainbow connection," the duo sang.

Musgraves won two CMA Awards at the 53rd annual ceremony: Music Video of the Year and Female Vocalist of the Year.

"Ultimately, I just want to say that I feel that the female creative spirit, female energy, it's really needed right now," she said, accepting the Vocalist prize. "It's really important. And I feel like it's something that earth needs. So whether it's me that's up here or any of the other women in this category, I just think that it's a beautiful thing, and I'm very appreciative."

Women unite with Little Big Town on 'Girl Crush'

Little Big Town has a girl crush on country music's newest up-and-coming female artists.

The multiplatinum-selling vocal group invited Lindsay Ell, Maddie & Tae, Kelsea Ballerini, Ashley McBryde, Carly Pearce and Runaway June to share its spotlight at the CMAs.

Maddie & Tae's Maddie Marlow said the duo was getting to sing beside "some of their favorite girls" in any genre during the performance.

"All of the artists singing this song together is going to make a really cool statement and hopefully wake everyone up to see how many incredible women should be given opportunities in country music."

McBryde, who won the CMA Award for New Artist of the Year, said she and Runaway June's Jennifer Wayne were shaking when they walked off the rehearsal stage.

"It's not just nerves," she said. "It's because of the power and what is happening, just the energy that is sparkling through everybody. When a song is this good, it's easy to perform it well. And everybody nailed it. Those magic moments are so rare. You should hold on to them. If your hands are shaking, you should just embrace it."

Garth Brooks is still unstoppable

As he stood on stage accepting the night's top prize ‚Äî Entertainer of the Year ‚Äî Garth Brooks made a point to mention a few of his favorite performances of the night.

‚ÄúLuke Combs, wherever you‚Äôre at, this has got your name on it in the future,‚Äù he said, pointing to the award.

But apparently, Brooks might need to retire again before that happens.

In a year when Eric Church and Carrie Underwood were on a tireless mission to win the award for the first time ‚Äî and on a female-driven show that suggested a collective eagerness for a woman to win again ‚Äî Brooks took it home, for a record seventh time.
