New York

New York: The remains of two people who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack at the World Trade Center were positively identified this week, as officials continued the difficult and heart-wrenching task of returning victims to their families. The announcement came days before the 20th anniversary of an attack that killed nearly 3,000 people when hijacked commercial jets flew into the twin towers, struck the Pentagon and crashed into a Pennsylvania meadow. ‚ÄúNo matter how much time passes since Sept. 11, 2001, we will never forget, and we pledge to use all the tools at our disposal to make sure all those who were lost can be reunited with their families,‚Äù said Dr. Barbara A. Sampson, the chief medical examiner of the city of New York. Technicians in the medical examiner‚Äôs office have been working for years to match thousands of body fragments recovered from the World Trade Center rubble with known victims but haven‚Äôt been able to extract useable DNA in many cases. The identifications announced Tuesday were the first since October 2019. One set of remains was linked to Dorothy Morgan, of Hempstead, New York, who was a broker for Marsh & McLennan. Officials also matched remains recovered in 2001, 2002 and 2006 to a single victim, whose family asked that his name be withheld.

North Carolina

North Dakota

Ivermectin has a limited scope for human treatment, sometimes prescribed for worms, scabies and head lice. It is more popular in veterinary form as a treatment for parasitic infections and infestations in cows and horses. North Dakota health officials say data on ivermectin sickness is limited, and poison control has only documented a couple of such cases. But Dr. Joshua Ranum of West River Regional Medical Center said the stories are out there. ‚ÄúThe ivermectin issue is interesting,‚Äù Ranum said. ‚ÄúWe of course live out in farm and ranch country. I‚Äôve had a lot of people tell me that the cows didn‚Äôt get their full dose of ivermectin because some of it accidentally went down the hatch.‚Äù The veterinary form of ivermectin has high concentrations of the drug because of the high body mass of horses and cows. Adverse effects in humans include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased consciousness, confusion, hallucinations, seizures, coma and death. There are better and safer options, according to Ranum and state Health Department spokesman Kirby Kruger. They pointed to monoclonal antibody drugs, steroids and antivirals like remdesivir.

Ohio

The commission held nine public hearings around the state earlier this month looking for input on a new map, which is meant to end the current gerrymandered maps. Voters approved constitutional amendments in 2015 and 2018 that created a new process for drawing both state legislative and congressional district maps this year and set up the independent commission. Creating a 10-year map requires a majority vote of the commission, including both Democrats. Creating a four-year map requires a simple majority without both Democrats.

Oklahoma

Oregon

Multnomah County, like Portland, has ordered all employees to be vaccinated by Oct. 18, including the sheriff‚Äôs office.

Pennsylvania

Harrisburg: A statewide mask mandate for schools went into effect Tuesday, with some districts in open defiance of the Wolf administration, while GOP leaders in the state House planned to come back to Harrisburg early to mount a legislative response. The state health secretary‚Äôs order that students, staff and visitors at K-12 schools and child care facilities are required to wear masks while indoors, regardless of COVID-19 vaccination status, has provoked outrage from some parents, students and school board members who say the decision should remain local. Some districts faced anti-mask protests as students returned to class after the long Labor Day weekend. Meanwhile, the Tamaqua Area School Board in Schuylkill County flouted the mask mandate by voting to keep face coverings optional. The superintendent of Hamburg Area School District in Berks County said masks would remain optional pending the outcome of a special school board meeting to discuss the statewide mandate. Late Tuesday, the board voted 5-3 to adhere to the Department of Health order and require masks, WFMZ reports. In central Pennsylvania, the Central York School Board expressed disdain for the mask mandate and said it would give a ‚Äúgrace period‚Äù for students to come into compliance.

Rhode Island

Providence: Local police organizations are questioning Mayor Jorge O. Elorza‚Äôs judgment after he hired a civilian with no experience in law enforcement to be the city‚Äôs first-ever police major instead of considering the Black officers who applied for the position. Elorza chose Michael Stephens, who has no experience in law enforcement, aside from graduating from the citizens academy in 2016. Stephens was a recreation director and NCAA referee before his appointment as police major, The Boston Globe reports. The National Association of Black Law Enforcement Officers Chairman Charles Wilson said the mayor‚Äôs decision in appointing a civilian without experience over qualified Black law enforcement officers was demeaning. Stephens is also Black. Stephens will manage oversight on police training and be responsible for the recruitment and training of police recruits. According to Wilson, three Black officers applied for the major‚Äôs position. The mayor chose Elorza instead. Providence City Council President John Igliozzi proposed that the mayor change the job title from police major to public safety community-police liaison because of the backlash from the police organizations.

South Carolina

Charleston: Authorities shut down a road for more than an hour Tuesday to investigate a bomb threat that turned out to be a wedding dress, Charleston Police said. Someone who saw a woman cram an oversized package into a mailbox called 911, Charleston Police spokesman Charles Francis said in a statement. Officers responded and determined the package contained a wedding dress that a woman was trying to return by mail, Francis said. The road was reopened after more than an hour. The statement did not say if the wedding dress was damaged.

South Dakota

Sioux Falls: The City Council has capped the number of retail stores that can sell medical marijuana at five. The council signed off Tuesday night on a proposal coming from Mayor Paul TenHaken‚Äôs office. But council members halved the $100,000 license fee that City Hall wanted and will allow the licenses to be sold on the secondary market. ‚ÄúThe Sioux Falls City Council, by making a license worth $50,000 and transferrable, has just made dispensary licenses into liquor licenses,‚Äù Drew Duncan, a Sioux Falls attorney and lobbyist for clients in South Dakota‚Äôs gambling and alcohol industry, said via social media following the 7-1 vote. A new liquor license in Sioux Falls costs about $200,000, but a state-set cap on the number of them has driven up the price on the secondary market to $300,000 or higher. TenHaken and supporters of barring the transfer of dispensary licenses worry that allowing them to be sold on the secondary market will give them an artificial value, just as has happened with liquor licenses. But the majority of the council decided without allowing a license to be owned outright, the city‚Äôs medical marijuana rules would unduly restrict a retailer‚Äôs ability to grow their business.

Tennessee

Nashville: A panel has approved $65 million in state incentives for Oracle Corp. as the company plans to bring 8,500 jobs and an investment topping $1 billion to the fast-growing capital city over the coming decade. The State Funding Board‚Äôs approval of the FastTrack grant came during a meeting Tuesday. In April, Nashville Mayor John Cooper‚Äôs office announced that the Austin, Texas-based computer technology company plans to build the new campus with 1.2 million square feet of office space. Documents show the jobs will have an average salary of $110,000. Oracle paid $254 million for 60 acres and is offering $175 million upfront for public infrastructure, including a pedestrian bridge over the Cumberland River, environmental cleanup, a sewer pump station and a riverfront park, the mayor‚Äôs office has said. Half of Oracle‚Äôs future property taxes ‚Äì which the company estimates will be roughly $18 million annually when the project is fully built ‚Äì would reimburse the company for the upfront investment, without interest payments, with the other half going into the city‚Äôs general operating fund, Cooper‚Äôs office has said. The move would surpass the expansion of Amazon, which in 2018 announced it would bring 5,000 jobs through a $230 million investment.

Texas

Dallas: Gov. Greg Abbott on Tuesday defended a new state law banning most abortions that also does not provide exceptions for cases of rape or incest, saying it does not force victims to give birth ‚Äì even though it prohibits abortions before many women know they‚Äôre pregnant. Abbott, a Republican, said Texas would strive to ‚Äúeliminate all rapists from the streets‚Äù while taking questions during his first press conference since the law took effect last week. The comments drew new criticism from opponents of the biggest curb on abortion in the U.S. since the medical procedure was legalized a half-century ago. The Texas law prohibits abortions once medical professionals can detect cardiac activity, which is usually about six weeks into a pregnancy. Though abortion providers in Texas say the law is unconstitutional, they say they are abiding by it. ‚ÄúHis comments are confusing to me because they certainly do not seem to reflect the realities of this law,‚Äù said Amy Jones, the chief executive officer of the Dallas Area Rape Crisis Center. Recent surveys by the U.S. Department of Justice found that most rapes go unreported to police. ‚ÄúCertainly it is in our mission statement to work to end sexual violence ‚Äì that is why we exist ‚Äì but we are also very aware that that is an aspirational goal that yes, we do believe that this is a preventable crime, but it if it were that easy, rape would no longer exist,‚Äù Jones said.

Utah

Brian Head: In the midst of record tourism statewide, Gov. Spencer Cox helped park staff and charity partners break ground Tuesday on a new visitor center at Cedar Breaks National Monument. The center has been a decade in the making, built with a combined $6 million in funds from fees, donations, and funding from Iron County, the National Park Service, the Zion Forever Project charity and organizations. Superintendent Kathleen Gondor did a ‚Äúhappy dance‚Äù as she opened the groundbreaking ceremony near the popular Point Supreme overlook, which is currently closed to the public because of the construction. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just going to give us that sense of place instead of a bunch of pullouts along the road,‚Äù she said, echoing a sentiment that Cedar Breaks is a ‚Äúdrive-thru‚Äù park. Cox said there was ‚Äúevery right to be excited,‚Äù and he was glad to see partnerships work as visitation soars in the lesser-known park. ‚ÄúSo many people even in Utah don‚Äôt know about it, still,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAmericans are rediscovering America, and Utahns are rediscovering Utah.‚Äù But with increased visitors comes an increased responsibility to make sure those visitors have a good experience and recreate responsibly, something Cox said he hopes the visitor center will help people to do.

Vermont

Waterbury: Three state troopers who are accused of being involved in a scheme to create fraudulent COVID-19 vaccination cards have resigned, state police said Tuesday. Troopers Shawn Sommers and Raymond Witkowski resigned Aug. 10, a day after a fellow trooper told supervisors about the alleged scheme. Trooper David Pfindel resigned Sept. 3 following further investigation, according to a state police news release. The three ex-troopers are suspected of having varying roles in the making of fraudulent vaccination cards, according to the release. ‚ÄúThe accusations in this case involve an extraordinary level of misconduct ‚Äì a criminal violation of the law ‚Äì and I could not be more upset and disappointed,‚Äù Col. Matthew T. Birmingham, director of the Vermont State Police, said in the release. ‚ÄúIf these allegations are proved to be true, it is reprehensible that state troopers would manipulate vaccination cards in the midst of a pandemic, when being vaccinated is one of the most important steps anyone can take to keep their community safe from COVID-19.‚Äù Sommers and Witkowski both joined the Vermont State Police in July 2016. Pfindel was hired in January 2014, police said. Federal authorities are investigating the allegations.

Virginia

Danville: A part of southside Virginia that has relatively lower rates of vaccination against COVID-19 is seeing increasing interest in the shots. The Danville Register & Bee reports that it appears the most recent surge in infections has spurred more residents to roll up their sleeves in the Pittsylvania-Danville Health District. Data from the Virginia Department of Health shows that inoculations jumped about 50% in August compared to July. Nearly two-thirds of the almost 5,700 shots were first doses. ‚ÄúNumbers of vaccinations are increasing as of late, which we welcome and consider a positive step by the community,‚Äù Dr. Scott Spillmann, director of the local health district, told the newspaper. ‚ÄúWe ask everyone who is not yet fully vaccinated to do so as soon as possible.‚Äù Southside Virginia trails the rest of the state when it comes to vaccination rates. As of Friday, 51% of adults in Danville were fully inoculated. In Pittsylvania County, 47% of adults were fully vaccinated. Statewide, more than two-thirds of adults have received a full COVID-19 vaccine series. Meanwhile, Danville and Pittsylvania County combined are seeing about 52 new coronavirus infections a day because of the delta variant.

Washington

Longview: A recent increase in COVID-19 deaths has overwhelmed a southwest Washington county‚Äôs storage capacity, prompting the coroner to ask the commissioners to declare an emergency to allow the county to bring in a refrigeration trailer. Cowlitz County commissioners agreed Tuesday to the request to help expand capacity until the new morgue is ready for staff to move into in about a month. The Daily News reports Cowlitz County Health and Human Services data for the past week is incomplete, but at least eight county residents died due to COVID-19 between Aug. 31 and Sept. 6. The residents ranged in age from their 40s to 90s, and seven of the residents had been hospitalized. Coroner Tim Davidson said the morgue and the county‚Äôs funeral homes are maxed out on capacity, and they are ‚Äúbeing creative‚Äù to maintain cold storage. All together, the facilities can typically hold 45 bodies and right now have about 65, he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just doing our best that we can to preserve the dignity of the deceased from this point forward until they can be processed for their families,‚Äù Davidson said. The morgue can hold 10 bodies but is currently ‚Äúway above that,‚Äù using gurney tables in the cooling rooms to handle the increase, he said. The new morgue under construction will be able to hold 50 in cold storage.

West Virginia

Fayetteville: The state‚Äôs largest annual festival will require most people in attendance to wear masks when Bridge Day is held this fall amid the coronavirus pandemic in America‚Äôs newest national park. Tens of thousands of people typically show up on the third Saturday of October to watch parachutists, zip liners and rappellers on the 876-foot-high New River Gorge Bridge in Fayetteville. Masks will be required at the festival regardless of vaccination status, and social distancing must be observed whenever possible, the Bridge Day Commission said in a statement. People come from across the world to attend the event. Festivalgoers typically line the center of the 3,000-foot-long bridge shoulder-to-shoulder trying to get a good look at parachutists catapulting themselves off the nation‚Äôs third-highest bridge. Exceptions to the mask mandate include those at the time of their participation ‚Äì be it in the air, during a 5-kilometer run, while rafting in the New River or on a zip line. But they‚Äôll have to mask up before and after, the statement said. Social distancing will be next to impossible on the crowded bridge itself, but organizers said it will be required on the festival‚Äôs perimeters. Bridge Day is the only day of the year the bridge is open to pedestrian traffic. The pandemic forced last year‚Äôs event to be canceled.

Wisconsin

Madison: A new report suggests people are buying dramatically more alcohol as the COVID-19 pandemic drags on. Revenue from state excise taxes on alcohol during the fiscal year that ended June 30 totaled $73.8 million, up almost 17% from $63.3 million the previous year, according to preliminary data from the state Department of Revenue cited in the report from the nonpartisan Wisconsin Policy Forum. If the preliminary data holds, the increase would be the biggest proportional increase the state has seen since 1972, the report said. The rise in alcohol tax collection exceeded 2.4% in only one year between 2009 and 2020, the report said. Alcohol excise taxes in Wisconsin are based on the volume sold, not price. Beer is taxed at about 6.5 cents per gallon. Wine is taxed at 25 cents per gallon if it has an alcohol content of 14% or less. The report did not examine sales tax revenue on alcohol. Most states have seen a bump in alcohol tax revenues during fiscal year 2021. The report said increased alcohol consumption is ‚Äúperhaps unsurprising‚Äù given rising stress related to personal health, job losses, school challenges and a lack of leisure activities during the pandemic.

Wyoming

Cheyenne: Wyoming Supreme Court Justice Michael K. Davis plans to retire in January, opening the way for Gov. Mark Gordon to make his first appointment to the high court. Davis plans to retire Jan. 16 after a decade on the state‚Äôs highest court, Chief Justice Kate M. Fox said in a statement Tuesday. Davis served as chief justice for three years, stepping down from that role July 1. He was a state district judge for four years before being named to the Supreme Court. He previously was an attorney in private practice. He graduated with honors from the University of Wyoming law school in 1980. Former Gov. Matt Mead, a Republican, named all five current justices over his two terms in office. Gordon, also a Republican, will choose the next justice from a list of three names submitted to him by the state Judicial Nominating Commission. The commission plans to accept expressions of interest from qualified people through Oct. 1. Wyoming requires Supreme Court justices to be at least 30, ‚Äúlearned in the law,‚Äù a judge or attorney for at least nine years, a U.S. citizen and a Wyoming resident for at least three years.

From USA TODAY Network and wire reports

search_result.title: A day later, no update on shooting of two Delmarva Power contractors
search_result.text:
Two Delmarva Power contractors were shot in west Wilmington Monday afternoon, according to police and a company official.

On Monday, one of the victims was said to be in critical condition and the other in stable condition.

Nearly 24 hours later, police have declined to comment further on the circumstances surrounding the shooting, nor have they given updates on the conditions of the victims.

Here is what we know about the situation so far, and what we don't.

What we know

Both men were working on a gas main on the 1800 block of West Second Street when they were shot just after 1:30 p.m. Monday.

One victim, 31, was in critical condition as of Monday afternoon. The other, 48, was said to be stable.

At least 10 bullet casing were seen at the scene.

The shooting happened in a residential neighborhood.

Neighbors said they did not hear the shots.

Residents also said Delmarva did not return to the neighborhood to resume work on Tuesday.

Police told residents trying to return to their houses on the block to come back later Monday evening after they finished investigating.

What we don't know

Details about the shooter: Police did not say whether they had a suspect, nor did they release any details on a potential suspect.

Is the shooter still at large? This is unclear. Wilmington Police declined to answer whether they have any leads on a suspect, are looking for one, took a suspect into custody or made an arrest.

What prompted the shooting? Authorities have not said whether they think the shooter had a motive.

Did the shooter fire at the contractors directly or were they caught in crossfire? Police declined to answer this question.

Where were the victims shot? Wilmington Police's spokesperson did not answer when asked where the men were wounded.

Who were the victims? Law enforcement and Delmarva Power said they could not release the victims' names.

What condition are the victims in? Police declined to give an update on the health status of the victims. The last, and only, update they gave came at 2:59 p.m. on Monday.

Is this shooting related to Tuesday morning's nearby shooting? A few blocks away, another shooting injured a 27-year-old man Tuesday morning. Police declined to say whether they believe the shootings are connected.

Is the neighborhood safe? Authorities didn't answer whether it is safe to return to that area.

Delmarva Power's response: A spokesman for Delmarva Power declined to say whether it was taking any precautions for its workers in the city on Monday, and did not give an update on the victims.

What Delmarva Power Says

On Monday afternoon, Delmarva Power released this statement:

"A shooting occurred injuring two contractors working on a gas main modernization project in Wilmington, Del. Our contractors were installing a new gas main and service lines to homes and businesses near 1807 W 2nd St. in Wilmington when the event occurred. Both contractors have been transported to the hospital and local authorities are investigating the incident. We work closely with our contractors every day on projects across our service area and this event impacts all of us at Delmarva Power. Our focus is now on our contractors, their families and coworkers, and our Delmarva Power employees."

What police say

On Monday afternoon, Wilmington Police released this statement:

"Wilmington Police are investigating a shooting incident that occurred just after 1:30 p.m. in the 1800 block of West 2nd Street. "Police located two male gunshot victims, who were both transported to the hospital for treatment. One of the victims, a 48-year-old male, is listed in stable condition. The second victim, a 31-year-old male, is listed in critical condition. "This incident remains under investigation and further details will be released when possible. "Anyone with information about this incident is encouraged to contact Detective Steven Bender at (302) 576-3621. You can also provide information to Delaware Crime Stoppers at ‚Ä™1-800-TIP-3333 or ‚Ä™delawarecrimestoppers.org."

What Mayor Mike Purzycki's Office Says

The mayor's office has not responded to The News Journal's request for comment.

search_result.title: Wilmington shootings surge. Mayor meets with community on solutions
search_result.text:
The brazen killing of a 14-year-old boy during the early evening hours Tuesday followed by a series of shootings in the days that followed prompted Wilmington Mayor Mike Purzycki to meet with area residents Friday to discuss ways to combat the surge in gun violence.

Despite only one of the 21 people shot so far this month in Wilmington occurring in the northeastern section of the city, Purzycki and other officials gathered with residents of the city‚Äôs 1st District to discuss ways to tackle the spike.

Speaking to a crowd of roughly 150 people ‚Äì including children, religious and community leaders, elected officials and residents from throughout the city ‚Äì Purzycki said that the shooting of 14-year-old Christopher Smith while riding his bike was particularly poignant, but the discussion Friday extended to all the shootings in Wilmington.

"We are never going to rid the world of violence, but if we can do the basics, we can make a much safer city but it‚Äôs not just up to me and the chief and the people who work for me, it‚Äôs up to all of us," Purzycki said after outlining some of the steps the city is taking to address the root causes of the violence.

Those steps, the mayor said, include regular street cleaning across the city, stronger code enforcement to improve building conditions for renters, upgrading to LED lighting with the capability to add surveillance cameras, and using the majority of the $55 million slated for Wilmington from the American Rescue Plan to improve neighborhoods.

Purzycki also stressed that the community can put pressure on state lawmakers to change gun laws, suggesting that Delaware doesn't need an open carry law.

"We do not have to be an open carry state," he said, remarking that it creates a culture that glorifies guns. "We don‚Äôt have to be Wyoming."

The crowd gathered outside the pool house at P.S. du Pont Middle School on West 34th Street, less than a block away from where Smith was gunned down Tuesday evening while hanging out with a friend near Riverview Cemetery.

At times, emotions ran high during the roughly hour-long discussion, with some attendees expressing frustration with Purzycki's focus on improving housing quality and overall living conditions for the city's poorer residents.

"I came here today thinking you were going to talk about gun violence, not about your financial plans," one attendee said after Purzycki finished his opening remarks. "I‚Äôm not worried about L&I and I‚Äôm not worried about picking up no damn trash. I‚Äôm worried about young kids not being shot. What are you going to do about that Mr. Mayor?"

With another week left in June, Delaware‚Äôs largest city has seen 21 people shot, the most in a single month since September when 23 people were shot. This brings the tally of people shot in Wilmington this year to 73, 14 fatally, the most people shot this early in the year since 2017, the city‚Äôs record year for shootings and homicides.

YOUNG TEEN KILLED:14-year-old boy killed in Wilmington shooting Tuesday

VIOLENT CRIME SPIKES:Shootings plague Wilmington hours after 24-year-old man shot in busy park

MORE SHOOTINGS:Teen shot in Wilmington's Hilltop neighborhood

Shootings across the country have become more brash, with violent incidents occurring in the afternoon and early evening hours rather than late at night under the cover of darkness.

More than half of all incidents statewide occurred between 5:00 p.m. and midnight, according to a Delaware Criminal Justice Council Statistical Analysis Center report on shootings in 2019. Wilmington accounted for 57 percent of shooting incidents statewide occurring between 6 a.m. and midnight, with 19 occurring between noon and 5 p.m., 27 shooting incidents each happened between 5 and 9 p.m. and 9 p.m. to midnight, according to the report.

The fact that the latest shootings in Wilmington occurred during daylight hours in parks and other places where large crowds gather further stress this trend ‚Äì one that city officials say requires the community‚Äôs help to address.

City officials say shooters no longer care if they are seen, expecting witnesses to remain mum for fear of retaliation. Few people come forward to help capture suspects and secure justice for the victims and their families.

"It‚Äôs as if the perpetrators of the crimes are not afraid that anybody is going to call them out," Purzycki said. "This is not a police issue. This is society‚Äôs problem. We‚Äôve screwed this up fairly well, and somehow we have to figure out how to solve it."

Wilmington activist the Rev. Derrick ‚ÄúPastor D‚Äù Johnson called on the mayor to include people who have developed a rapport with residents in discussions of solutions, remarking that those who are considered "community partners" aren't the ones who are on the street interacting with the community.

Johnson stressed that Wilmington officials need to focus on the culture that attracts youth to gang life and eliminate the political back-and-forth that holds back progress. Purzycki pledged to call Johnson on Monday to work together toward a solution.

Those attracted to gang life are looking to feel significant and important, Johnson said.

"The streets tell them they are significant, and murder tells them they matter," he said.

search_result.title: Shots halt event at Haynes Park in Wilmington
search_result.text:
Sean O'Sullivan

The News Journal

WILMINGTON ‚Äì Shots interrupted a charity basketball tournament Sunday evening at Haynes Park, according to police.

It appears no one was wounded in the chaotic situation, Cpl. Jamaine Crawford, a Wilmington police spokesman, said Sunday night.

According to witnesses, a group of young men started shooting when the basketball courts were full and children were playing on nearby jungle gyms, causing all in the park to scatter.

Police tape blocked the entrance to the park at Franklin and 32nd streets and there were at least a half-dozen yellow plastic markers on the ground, identifying the location of shell casings.

No one interviewed knew why the young men started shooting and residents in the area said the park was normally a safe place to let children play and Sunday's shooting was an aberration.

Cecilia Williams organized the charity event for her sister Francine Wallace, who was seriously injured in a fatal June 16 fire at her Bird Street home.

"We were raising money for a good cause. Some boys just came and they started shooting at everyone in the park! It makes no sense. Wilmington City Council, Mayor Williams Help!" she told a reporter.

Lamotte Scales died in the June 16 blaze and another woman was burned. Wallace's injures could keep her in the hospital for more than a year, according to the family.

The incident was reported about 5:20 p.m., police said and shortly after the shooting more than a dozen police cars ringed the park and several were inside the park itself near playground equipment.

At least a dozen officers were seen walking through the park, apparently collecting evidence related to the shooting.

Wilmington Fire Chief Anthony Goode also was present, but said he was not there in an official capacity. He walked from his nearby home when he heard the commotion, Goode said.

A woman who lives directly across from the park and identified herself as Niya said she heard the shots and then saw people running. She also had a moment of brief panic because one of her children was playing in the park, but seconds later she saw her child running home.

"It is a good area, we don't have stuff like this happen," she said, adding she was surprised police were not on hand before shots rang out because the crowd for the event was so large.

search_result.title: Sixth person shot in Wilmington in 24 hours
search_result.text:
Brittany Horn, and Jenna Pizzi

The News Journal

A 24-year-old man who was shot in the leg Thursday afternoon marks the sixth person to be injured in a Wilmington shooting in the last 24 hours.

City police were called shortly at about 4:44 p.m. to the area of West 27th and Tatnall streets late Thursday afternoon for a man down. Upon arrival, officers found him with a gunshot wound to the leg and buttocks area, Sgt. Andrea Janvier said.

Multiple units were on scene and detectives closed the intersection and surrounding block of West 27th and Enterprise streets for investigation purposes. The man was transported to Christiana Hospital for further care and is described as stable, Janvier said.

The shooting remains under investigation. Anyone with information in reference to this incident is asked to call Detective Chatles Puit at (302) 576-3628.

Tips also may be given on the Wilmington Police Confidential Tip Line at (302) 576-3990, by sending texts starting with TIP WILMINGTON to 888777 and providing them through Delaware Crime Stoppers at (800) TIP-3333 or www.tipsubmit.com.

Several vehicles were damaged by the gunfire that rocked the block around 5 p.m. as many returned home after work. The block was otherwise quiet Thursday night as the incident marked the sixth person shot in Wilmington in the last 24 hours.

Four people were injured late Wednesday afternoon in what police are saying were two separate and unrelated shootings. Another man was shot late Wednesday night.

Thursday afternoon's shooting marks the 104th shooting in the city this year, leaving 117 injured and 22 dead from incidents of gun violence.

Wilmington leaders said they are fed up with the increase in crime, saying more must be done to combat its causes in the city.

"We want to do anything necessary to clean this up," said Richard Smith, president of the state NAACP. "People are scared. You've got thousands of dollars in guns on the street with people killing each other."

"I am angry at myself for sitting on the sidelines," said New Castle County Councilman Jea Street, speaking during the public comment portion of a Wilmington City Council meeting.

Street said he wants to see more programs implemented and questioned if the federal Violence Reduction Network program announced last year has been put in place and is being effective in Wilmington.

"What has been reduced?" he asked. "Nothing has been reduced. Nothing has changed."

Council President Theo Gregory said he will look into the implementation and effectiveness of the VRN program, but agreed that the city is lacking in its social service offerings to residents.

"This crime is a continuation of an epidemic in this city where there is a failure of families, support, schools," Gregory said. "We have got to find a way to recapture some of this stuff."

Councilwoman Loretta Walsh and Councilman Mike Brown turned to the police department, saying more could be done to better deploy officers to be more effective.

Walsh said officers are being sent to the same locations and are not given the proper deployment to effectively fight crime in those communities. She suggested the department leadership should consult again with the report issued by the Wilmington Crime Commission earlier this year and the commission's suggestions for a more strategic deployment of resources.

Brown, who is chairman of the council's public safety committee, said the department should focus on taking illegal guns off the streets and out of the hands of those who are prohibited from having them.

"Irresponsible people putting their hands on guns," Brown said, noting that in years past the department had a group of officers that went on "gun checks" to ensure that those on probation and parole did not have a weapon.

search_result.title: Man found shot outside Penn Cinema IMAX in Wilmington
search_result.text:
robin brown

The News Journal

A shooting victim was found late Tuesday night outside a Riverfront movie theater, Wilmington police said Wednesday, but investigation determined the man was shot several blocks away.

The 20-year-old was shot in the back, Sgt. Andrea Janvier said, and investigation determined the shooting occurred in the area of Oak and Marshall streets.

No suspect information or details of the circumstances of the shooting were available as the investigation continued.

A 911 call at 11:23 p.m. reported the injured man in the parking lot of the Penn Cinema IMAX Theater in the 400 block of S. Madison St., Janvier said.

New Castle County paramedics treated him at the scene before he was taken to Christiana Hospital, she said. His condition was not available, but he was described as stable.

The place where police say evidence of his shooting was found is not part of the Riverfront area, but west of I-95 where residential Marshall Street comes to a T at Oak Street.

Police have not said how the shooting victim arrived at the movie theater or why he was there instead of seeking medical attention.

The situation echoed a shooting on Nov. 30, 2013, when an injured Philadelphia man told police he was shot at the Riverfront.

The 33-year-old was driving near West Fourth and North Van Buren streets shortly after 2:30 a.m. when he flagged down a city officer. He said he was standing outside the Chase Center, heard gunfire, realized he was hit in the arm and was trying to find a hospital, police said. The officer escorted him to Wilmington Hospital, where he was treated for the minor injury and released, they said.

Residents, business people and visitors were shocked by what was labeled as the first gun violence at the Riverfront, a relatively safe area where tens of millions of dollars have been poured over many years into housing and business development.

Weeks later, there was relief on the Riverfront.

The taxpayer-supported Riverfront Development Corp. announced it had conducted an unprecedented independent investigation of the incident, concluding there was no evidence the shooting occurred at the Riverfront, calling the area an ‚Äúextremely safe destination for shopping and recreation.‚Äù

Following the RDC announcement, Wilmington Police Department also issued a statement saying its own investigation also found no evidence of the shooting having occurred at the Riverfront ‚Äì and concluded the injured man had lied.

‚ÄúWe have a duty to thoroughly investigate any alleged shooting incident, and lacking any physical evidence, our starting point is where the victim claims the incident occurred,‚Äù then-police spokesman Cpl. Mark Ivey said.

Police, who routinely report victim accounts of shootings‚Äô circumstances, also revealed a search warrant executed on the Philadelphia man‚Äôs vehicle turned up $116,000 in cash.

By that time, however, news of the alleged Riverfront shooting had alarmed Wilmington residents, leadership and business leaders, especially coming as the city struggled with a year of record gun violence.

Between the initial report of the Philadelphia man‚Äôs shooting and the time his account of where it happened was labeled a lie, Wilmington City Council voted unanimously to urge the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to investigate the ‚Äúpandemic‚Äù of gun violence in the city.

The injured Philadelphian was the 147th person shot in the city that year.

Emphasizing that the city‚Äôs Riverfront is a safe area, RDC Executive Director Michael S. Purzycki said at the time, ‚ÄúWe are absolutely committed to making sure it stays that way.‚Äù

Tuesday night‚Äôs shooting victim was the 60th person injured in gunfire in the city this year, including 14 who were killed.

Police ask anyone with information about the shooting to call Detective Michael Gifford at (302) 576-3640. Information also may be given by calling the Wilmington Police Confidential Tip Line at (302) 576-3990 or sent in texts starting with TIP WILMINGTON to 888777.

search_result.title: Semi-automatics key factor in Wilmington violence
search_result.text:
Brittany Horn

The News Journal

When gunshots erupt in Wilmington, it's likely the firearm involved is a semi-automatic pistol with a large-capacity magazine. The combination of a quick-loading, high-powered weapon and extra ammunition is the reason so many shootings have multiple bullets fired ‚Äì and unintended victims in densely populated neighborhoods are being killed.

Wilmington police Chief Bobby Cummings said even novice shooters with such a gun can wield incredible firepower, able to scattershot rounds in a wide path. Some shooting scenes are littered with dozens of bullet holes and shell casings, which Forensic Services Unit investigators mark with orange cones or chalk circles as evidence to be tested.

‚ÄúObviously, the extended magazines are creating a significant threat, not only to the intended target, but people who may be in the general area at the time of a shooting incident,‚Äù Cummings said.

More than 20 casings, for example, were found in the 400 block of North Monroe Street after an Oct. 14 shooting that killed a man in the crossfire. It was one of 20 shootings citywide during the month.

In another case about three weeks later, police found 21 bullets pumped into a white Honda near a Southbridge bar, one of 11 shootings for November.

Wilmington ranks third in violence among 450 cities of its size, according to FBI, and has averaged 118 shooting victims each year for the past decade. Last year, there were 127.

The sound of multiple gunshots are a regular occurrence in places like the West Center City neighborhood, where residents compare scenes to something out of the ‚Äúwild, wild west.‚Äù

Brooke Allison, who moved her family out of West Center City two years ago after the spike in violence, said she's seen the way bullets take apart a family and a home. Her mother's back patio door was shattered in a shooting earlier this year and bullet holes still dot the wooden fence behind her house.

‚ÄúI used to hear bullets all the time ... one hit my screen door and I would be ducking to cover my kids,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMeanwhile, my kids are going, ‚ÄòOh there's a shooting ... and running to see the action.‚Äô Gunshots don't mean anything to these kids nowadays. They run to the scene and pull out their phones.‚Äù

A study released last month by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which was asked to study Wilmington crime by City Councilwoman Hanifa Shabazz, pointed to ‚Äúepidemic levels of urban gun violence‚Äù in the community. Last year, Wilmington ranked third among 450 cities of comparable size for most violent crimes behind Saginaw and Flint in Michigan, according to the FBI.

The state General Assembly and Gov. Jack Markell last year also established a special panel, the Wilmington Public Safety Strategies Commission, to make recommendations to the city and Police Department for combating crime, including better tracking firearms.

Mayor Dennis P. Williams has been criticized for not implementing all the suggestions, most recently on Tuesday in a letter by Assembly members who represent Wilmington in Dover.

So far, 123 shootings have happened this year in Wilmington . The city is on track to have the deadliest 12 months since 2013, with 141 victims and 24 killed.

One of the 2015 victims was Shurkri Brown, 32, whose arms, chest and face were hit by nine bullets, during a shooting near West Seventh and North West streets on April 3. A father of six, he still battles intense pain, depression and nightmares of the violence he endured.

‚ÄúI still relive it,‚Äù he said.

Scars map his body ‚Äì‚Äì reminders of bullets that tore through his skin, one just centimeters above his heart. Brown was in a coma for three days and hospitalized for weeks after the shooting. Even though Brown had prior experience with guns and knew plenty of people who had been shot, he couldn't imagine being hit nine times.

"I never had beef in the hood," Brown said. "I could go anywhere. But I guess he wanted to get me before I got him, even thought I wasn't trying to get him."

Wilmington police would not disclose what type of weapons are most commonly used in crimes, but Cummings and other officials said semi-automatic pistols with extended magazines are a favorite of criminals. In Philadelphia, for example, 65 percent of firearms recovered last year were semi-automatics, said Philadelphia police Department Officer Leeloni Palmiero.

The appeal is that semi-automatics are simple to use and relatively easy to obtain.

‚ÄúThis is the gangster gun,‚Äù said Jeremy Moore, who works at Starquest Shooters & Survival Supplies in Brandywine Hundred, as he held a Glock 19 semi-automatic, a black model weighing about 1.8 pounds when loaded with the standard 15 rounds.

He said the gun is the most popular in America ‚Äî light, easily concealable and straightforward to operate. The magazine holding the ammo has a spring that pops a new round into the firing chamber each time the trigger is squeezed. The bullet explodes from the barrel while a casing is expelled out the top of the weapon.

Even a shooter without much skill can unload all 15 bullets in less than 30 seconds, Moore said. Add an extended magazine, and the semi-automatic‚Äôs capacity can grow to 30 rounds.

Once emptied, a magazine ‚Äî also known as a "ladder" ‚Äî can easily be replaced with another fully loaded.

Unlike fully automatic weapons, which can fire a continuous stream of bullets and are illegal in Delaware, a semi-automatic discharges only when the trigger is pulled. But Cummings said the addition of the high-capacity magazines are being used by criminals to beef up semi-automatics to make them more like assault weapons.

"They can't get the weapons that can get them the firepower," he said, "so they're grabbing ladders instead."

By contrast, the weapon most commonly traced to criminal acts by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives in 2000 ‚Äì the .38-caliber Smith & Wesson revolver ‚Äì has a capacity of eight rounds.

The ATF has not conducted a similar national study on specific firearms since then, but the agency has tallied gun types tied to crimes in each state. In Delaware, pistols are overwhelmingly the top spot, with 522 recovered in 2014, compared to 187 revolvers.

The one constant is that the weapons are getting more and more powerful, especially with the addition of the detachable magazines, police said.

Police and gun sellers say the vast majority of firearm purchases are legal. Delaware also requires background checks for private parties selling or transferring firearms.

Criminals typically secure firearms through "straw purchases," in which a third-party person is paid to buy a gun. He or she passes the background check and makes the purchase legally, only to hand it over to the criminal.

A basic semi-automatic pistol retails for about $150, a price Moore speculated is a factor in their popularity with criminals.

‚ÄúGuys don‚Äôt want to buy something expensive because they‚Äôre going to buy it, shoot someone with it and get rid of it,‚Äù he said.

The Crime Commission report, which examined the gun trade in Wilmington, said ‚Äúthat most, if not all, of the firearms are the result of straw purchases.‚Äù The report said buyers can be a ‚Äúsingle mother or drug addict who purchases the firearms for shooters in exchange for money, narcotics, or both.‚Äù

Some guns come from break-ins, said Wilmington police Sgt. Andrea Janvier.

‚ÄúThey get them a lot of ways, whether it be through robbing a home where they‚Äôre stored or through straw purchases,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey do what they need to do to get their guns.‚Äù

Most of Delaware's guns were traced back to the First State purchases, though many were also linked to Pennsylvania, Maryland and Virginia. ATF data shows some came from as far as Texas and Florida.

Ron Palimere, owner of the Starquest gun store, said his employees see about one attempted straw purchase a month. Often a woman accompanied by a man will try to purchase a cheap gun. Employees suspecting this often offer alternatives to the buyer, as well as note the ramifications ‚Äî and 10-year jail sentence ‚Äî they may face if their purchased gun is used in a crime.

‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt feel comfortable with a sale, we don‚Äôt have a give a reason why we deny the purchase,‚Äù he said, adding that the ATF supports gun shop owners in their decisions. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre essentially the last line of defense before people get their hands on guns.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt affects me, too,‚Äù Palimere said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want the bad guys running around with guns, either.‚Äù

Delaware has no laws regulating large-capacity ammunition magazines, though anti-gun activists are pushing to ban the arms. A 2013 bill to prohibit the sales failed in the General Assembly.

Nine states prohibit or severely limit the use and possession of extended magazines, which generally are considered anything more than 15 bullets.

Los Angeles also banned the extended magazines in July, following a sharp increase in gun crime. The law went into effect in November, and the L.A. Police Department doesn‚Äôt have data yet to indicate the impact on the number of shootings.

The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday rejected an appeal from gun owners who challenged a ban on semi-automatic weapons and large-capacity magazines in Highland Park, Illinois, near Chicago.

Calls for more stringent gun control rules also recently spread in the aftermath of the San Bernardino, California, mass shooting that left 14 dead.

President Barack Obama, in a televised speech Dec. 6 said, ‚ÄúI know there are some who reject any gun safety measures. But the fact is that our intelligence and law enforcement agencies ‚Äî no matter how effective they are ‚Äî cannot identify every would-be mass shooter."

Obama previously called for tighter gun control laws in light of the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, shooting in December 2012 that killed 26.

Robert J. Cottrol, a George Washington University law professor and gun expert, has studied semi-automatic weapons and said they‚Äôre far more of a threat than rifles and other guns used in mass shootings.

"For all gun crimes, we are really talking about pistols rather than rifles of one sort or another," Cottrol said. "Obviously, you get the spectacular mass shooting occurring with rifles. But my reading of the statistics is something in the order of 100 people a year are killed, in those events as opposed to 10,000-15,000 homicides a year (by pistols), depending on the year."

He said criminals prefer semi-automatic pistols because they get the effectiveness and ability to conceal the hardware ‚Äì the same reason people carry them for self-defense.

The popularity, however, does not mean the criminals getting the guns understand the power, said Master Cpl. Mark Hoffman, of the Dover Police Department, which also is grappling with violence. The city has had 18 shootings this year, seven of which were fatal.

"We're seeing people who don't know how terminal gunfire is," he said.

Additional rounds fired mean more evidence for law enforcement to use for tracing weapons and linking crimes. Wilmington police scan shell casings using Match Point technology, an ottoman-sized black box in the evidence control room.

The machine analyzes and matches shell casings to others entered into a nation-wide database. When a shell casing is tied to another case, police can use that as evidence and link it to other crimes.

Police hope the machine will help determine whether four semi-automatics found in a white BMW following a high-speed car chase through the city on Nov. 3 were involved in other shootings around the city. Officials are awaiting results from the firearms examiner in Dover.

A MasterPiece Arms .45 Automatic Colt Pistol with an extended magazine sat next to the car's driver, Willie Brothers Jr., in plain view and within easy reach, police said. It was able to spit out nearly a round a second with a skilled shooter.

Brothers was charged in connection with a shooting on Oct. 29 along Jensen Drive, as well as a slew of other charges.

Police put out an alert earlier in the evening about the vehicle, adding that the vehicle and its probable driver were wanted in connection to multiple shootings in the city. Two Smith and Wesson .40 caliber handguns and a .45 caliber Sig Sauer 1911 were also found in the car, as well as .45 caliber, .40 caliber and .380 caliber ammunition.

Wilmington police won‚Äôt get into the details of how they analyze shell casings because they don‚Äôt want shooters to know what they do.

The Police Department in 2014 recorded 363 firearm recoveries, the most in Delaware, followed by Newark at 118 and Dover at 76, according to the ATF.

Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams and Cummings have said the Police Department is aggressively working to address crime and build better relationships with the community.

Last month was the first November in five years in which no one died of gun violence. The month had 11 shootings, down from a record 21 from November 2014.

Cummings also said police staff are equipped to handle the high-capacity weapons. While officers carry a standard-issue Smith and Wesson .40 caliber pistol with 15 rounds, members of the city's SWAT team have much more powerful weapons at their disposal in a moment‚Äôs notice, Cummings said.

"I‚Äôm not going to say that we are evenly matched, but we still have the ability to do our jobs," he said.

The CDC report released last month also recommended increasing collaboration between schools, hospitals and courts and sharing data in a risk assessment tool, ultimately used to determine how at-risk a child may be to commit violence, as well as wrap-around services combining mental health, mentoring, counseling and more.

Data shows the majority of shootings involve younger people, often between the ages of 13 and 17, in arguments that escalate from social media to physical altercations, according to the commission's report. Many locals note that instead of fighting with their fists, young people turn to guns.

Cummings said authorities aren‚Äôt backing down from seizing firearms and stopping violence, and are working with other agencies. So far this year, the Police Department has gotten 241 guns through patrols and investigations, 42 of which came from West Center City.

But there is plenty more work to do, he said.

"We are taking guns off the streets every day, and we are not the only ones,‚Äù Cummings said, ‚Äúso there have to be a lot of them out there.‚Äù

Contact Brittany Horn at (302) 324-2771 or bhorn@delawareonline.com. Follow her on Twitter at @brittanyhorn.

search_result.title: Gun murders, especially in Wilmington, continue to be toughest to ...
search_result.text:
The only gun violence killing in Wilmington this year where an arrest was made was caught on video.

Good quality footage showed a man chasing and shooting at Zah-Viaire Berry-Shivers on the afternoon of Jan. 26, according to court documents.

It was enough to identify and arrest a suspect, Andre Fletcher-Hargrow.

There have been 14 homicides incidents in Wilmington this year. Police made arrests in three others but none of them involved a gun.

Shootings remain the most difficult to solve.

In Berry-Shivers' death, because of the video, detectives were able to search social media and found Fletcher-Hargrow's picture through associates in previous investigations, court documents said.

Fingerprints on a car he touched in the video matched Fletcher-Hargrow's prints, according to court documents.

State and federal agents arrested him on June 13 in Upper Darby, Pennsylvania.

The families of victims in 11 other shooting deaths this year have yet to see that kind of closure.

Some other 2018 homicides have pending indictments, said a Wilmington police spokesman. That means suspects are identified, but not charged.

Dover police made arrests in all three of its 2018 homicide cases. New Castle County Police made arrests in or otherwise solved four of its six 2018 homicide incidents. Middletown police had one homicide this year and have made an arrest. State police made arrests or otherwise solved 86 percent of its seven 2018 homicide incidents.

Some homicide incidents had more than one victim, such as the two double shootings New Castle County Police have yet to solve. Others, such as any of the three murder-suicides committed in Delaware this year, don't require arrests for police to solve them.

Only three of this year's 18 homicide events outside Wilmington don't have a suspect in custody. Wilmington police made arrests in four of its 14 homicide events, 10 of which are shooting deaths.

"Wilmington is, unfortunately, a good place to commit murder," said Thomas Hargrove, founder of the Murder Accountability Project. "You're probably going to get away with it."

Hargrove was looking at Wilmington data reported to the FBI from 2012 to 2016. The Project is designed to track unsolved killings nationwide and make murder data public.

"In 58 percent, the killer walked," Hargrove said of Wilmington's 2012-16 clearance rate. "That's not good. When that happens, you should expect the murder rate to rise."

It did.

Last year was the worst on record for Wilmington gun violence ‚Äî 197 shot, 32 fatally.

Then the fever broke.

Shootings declined this year over last by 55 percent, according to Wilmington police data up to July 29. By that date last year, 103 people had been shot. This year, it was 46.

Murders reported by the department by July 29 fell from 21 last year to 15 this year.

"If the murder rate is down this year, that might suggest Wilmington police have done something important," Hargrove said. "It's possible that they've turned a corner."

WILMINGTON POLICING

As Wilmington crime stats fall, some feel it, some don't

Aside from the Fletcher-Hargrow arrest, Wilmington police this year cleared three other homicides, none of which involved guns.

A suspect was still on the scene when police arrived for a stabbing that injured several and killed one. In another stabbing, police followed a trail of blood to the suspect. Police also charged two adults with beating a 15-month-old to death in February.

Though there were fewer shooting deaths this year, solving them still is a challenge.

Wilmington Police Chief Robert Tracy has said efforts to keep officers more closely tied to their neighborhood beats is working, but he hasn't declared the mission complete.

He's said ending the killings will take a long time. He's said the community doesn't speak up when it doesn't trust police to solve crimes or keep its witnesses safe.

Col. Vaughn Bond, who leads New Castle County Police, said silence leaves families without justice, as he says it has for his agency's two unsolved 2018 homicide cases.

NEW CASTLE COUNTY

Bond angry about Belvedere double homicide

"There is a certain segment of the community determined they are not going to work with police," Bond said. "It's not about, necessarily, the police department. This is about providing answers to people who have lost their loved ones."

County police have six homicide incidents on the books so far this year.

Two were domestic killings, according to police. There was a murder-suicide on Aug. 7 in which the suspected killer is, obviously, dead. And there's a May 5 case in which police believe a man stabbed his girlfriend, leaving identifying evidence at the scene.

In another case, a homeowner shot a man police believe was in his house intending to burglarize it. The homeowner was not charged with a crime.

The March shooting in Ogletown that killed William Laws has four suspects in custody.

No one has been arrested for the May 24 gunfire killings of Thessalonians Berry and Isabel Cooper on Kiamensi Road or the June 24 shooting deaths of Vincent DiMenco and 15-year-old Doris Dorsey, who died in front of her own house in Belvedere.

Bond says there are people of interest in the case, but still wants people to speak up.

Solving gun crimes is difficult, Bond said, especially in gangland-style killings where a shooter may leave little evidence and fades into a crowd of possible suspects.

"You may get lucky and get some DNA, but many times you don't," Bond said. "Oftentimes, you have to rely on your investigation, and your investigation is going to rely on you being able to canvas an area to come up with witnesses to the incident."

There have been 31 homicide incidents statewide this year, some of which have more than one victim. Thirteen, all of which are shootings, don't have a suspect in custody.

Ten of them are in Wilmington. Two are double murders under New Castle County Police jurisdiction. And state police have one from July 6 in which they're trying to identify three people they believe were involved in shooting a man to death in Laurel.

Murder clearance rates are on the decline nationwide. The national murder clearance rate fell to 59.4 percent in 2016, the lowest since the FBI started tracking it.

Hargrove said clearance rates are falling largely because of limited police resources.

"By resources, I mean people, I mean technology, I mean laboratory capacity, I mean time for prosecutors to prosecute," Hargrove said. "Most of the time when you see a declining clearance rate it is a direct function of the fiscal health of the government."

He pointed to money crises in Illinois, with the country's lowest clearance rate, and in New Jersey, where police departments have shrunk and clearance rates have tumbled.

He said the average homicide victim is now a black man in an urban area, a setting where Hargrove said community police is required to make up for past failures.

"A police department that is on a first-name basis with the gangs, has regular communication with the gangs, are very much aware of who the leaders are and who the killers are within the groups, these are police departments that do a much better job of containing murder," Hargrove said.

search_result.title: Who is Travis Kelce? What Taylor Swift fans need to know
search_result.text:
Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce haven't done much to shake off rumors that they're dating.

The "Shake It Off" singer cheered excitedly as she watched Kelce and the Kansas City Chiefs dismantle the Chicago Bears in a 41-10 win at Arrowhead Stadium on Sunday. Swift shared a box suite with Donna Kelce, Travis' mother, and sported a Kansas City jacket.

Kelce and Swift were also spotted leaving the game together and driving away in the football star's vintage convertible, much to the delight of fans rooting for the match.

While neither Kelce nor Swift have publicly confirmed they are dating, the two have been linked since Kelce revealed he had been hoping to give Swift a friendship bracelet with his phone number on it at her Eras Tour concert at Arrowhead Stadium in July.

Here's everything Swifties need to know about Taylor's possible new beau:

S-W-I-F-T?:Taylor Swift mania takes over Chiefs vs. Jets game amid Travis Kelce dating rumors

SUNDAY NIGHT FOOTBALL:Chiefs vs Jets Sunday Night Football highlights: Kansas City wins, Taylor Swift celebrates

Travis Kelce's age, hometown, college

Kelce is 33 years old and is from Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

He played football at the University of Cincinnati from 2008 to 2012. He was selected by the Kansas City Chiefs in the third round of the 2013 NFL Draft and has played in Kansas City for his entire 11-year career so far.

Travis Kelce's career in numbers

Kelce has won two Super Bowls, been named a First-team All-Pro four times and been voted to eight Pro Bowls.

Kelce has 71 career touchdowns, recording 825 receptions for over 10,000 yards during his 11 seasons so far, putting him in the top five NFL tight ends of all time.

Kelce holds multiple NFL records, including the most seasons with 1,000-plus receiving yards by a tight end (seven) and receiving yards in a season by a tight end (1,416).

For all his work on the field, Kelce was named to the NFL's 2010s All-Decade Team.

OPINION:Who cares if Taylor Swift is dating NFL star Travis Kelce? After Sunday's game, everyone.

Who is Travis Kelce's brother?

Travis isn't the only member of his family to have a successful NFL career.

His older brother, Jason Kelce, is the starting center for the Philadelphia Eagles.

The 35-year-old also played football at the University of Cincinnati and was a sixth round pick by the Eagles in the 2011 NFL Draft. He has won one Super Bowl, been named a First-team All-Pro five times and been voted to six Pro Bowls.

The brothers famously played against each in Super Bowl LVII last year, which saw the Chiefs defeat the Eagles 38-35.

'New Heights' podcast

Travis and Jason Kelce co-host a popular podcast together called "New Heights," named in honor of their hometown of Cleveland Heights.

The brothers chat about life and football, and have even talked about Swift, with Travis sharing his attempt to slip the pop star his phone number before her show in Kansas City.

"I was disappointed that she doesn‚Äôt talk before or after her shows because she has to save her voice for the 44 songs that she sings," he said. "So, I was a little butt hurt I didn‚Äôt get to hand her one of the bracelets I made for her."

New episodes of the podcast are released every Wednesday.

"New Heights" premiered in 2022 and has quickly become one of the most popular sports podcasts in the U.S.

Travis Kelce's reality dating show, 'SNL' gig

Travis Kelce starred in a reality dating show in 2016 called "Catching Kelce." During the show, Kelce chose among 50 women from 50 states in a setup similar to "The Bachelor."

Kelce would take the women on dates to concerts, and on yachts and private jets.

"What these girls don't know is that I actually am as nervous as they are," Kelce said in one clip from the day he met the contestants.

The show was canceled after one season, lasting eight episodes.
